revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{original research|date=August 2018}} {{POV|date=February 2016}} The [[navel]] has been historically subject to many [[customs]], [[fashion]]s and taboos. Various cultures view the sexual and cultural significance of the navel differently, and these views have changed over time, which has shaped social mores relating to the navel in [[fashion design|design of clothing]] and social traditions and practices.
==Western culture== The public exposure of the male and female [[midriff]] and bare navel has been [[taboo]] at times in [[Western culture]]s, being considered [[Modesty|immodest]] or [[indecent]]. It was banned in some jurisdictions,<ref name="news">{{cite news|title=New code may reveal navel|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eLtPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gFMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3939,2026891&dq=navel+reveal&hl=en|accessdate=20 April 2012|newspaper=Mohave Daily Miner|date=24 March 1985}}</ref> with some arguing that it simulated an "[[erogenic]] [[Body orifice|orifice]]". Eventually, only female navel exposure was banned and not male because, it was argued, the simulation or upward displacement from vagina to navel was commonplace and obvious in women.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Elaine Perez Zickler|title=Elizabeth Bronfen, The Knotted Subject: Hysteria and Its Discontents |url=http://www.brynmawr.edu/bmrcl/Spring2001/Bronfen.html |volume=2 |number=2 |date=Spring 2001 |journal=Bryn Mawr Review of Comparative Literature |accessdate=16 March 2012}}</ref>
Community perceptions have changed and exposure of female midriff and navel is more accepted today and in some societies or contexts it is both fashionable and common, though not without its critics. The exposure of the male navel has not been as controversial nor as common, and is usually in the context of barechestedness. Exposure of the navel by females is commonly associated with the popularization of the [[bikini]], of the [[crop top]] and [[Low-rise (fashion)|low-rise clothing]].
===Film=== In the United States, the [[Motion Picture Production Code]], or Hays Code, enforced after 1934, banned the exposure of female navel in Hollywood films.<ref>*{{cite book |last1=Moseley |first1=Rachel |title=Fashioning Film Stars: Dress, Culture, Identity |date=2005 |publisher=British Film Institute |isbn=978-1-8445-7067-6 |page=136 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7dVkAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=navel }} *{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=WOdtTp2ALcTJ0AGhy8GeBQ&ct=result&id=__DqAAAAMAAJ&dq=hays+code+midriff&q=navel#search_anchor |title=The bikini book |author=Kelly Killoren Bensimon |publisher=Thames & Hudson |year=2006 |isbn=9780500513163 |page=22 }} *{{cite news|author=Ian Lendler|title=A timeline of TV censorship|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2007-07-31/living/censorship_1_tweety-bird-elvis-tea?_s=PM:LIVING|accessdate=16 March 2012|publisher=CNN|date=31 July 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120420210441/http://articles.cnn.com/2007-07-31/living/censorship_1_tweety-bird-elvis-tea?_s=PM:LIVING#|archive-date=20 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The [[National Legion of Decency]], a Roman Catholic body guarding over American media content, also pressured Hollywood to keep clothing that exposed certain parts of the female body, such as bikinis and low-cut dresses, from being featured in Hollywood movies.<ref>{{cite book|first=Frank A. |last=Salamone|title=Popular Culture in the Fifties|page=76|publisher=University Press of America|year= 2001 |isbn=0-7618-2103-1}}</ref> [[File:Beach Party Annette Funicello Frankie Avalon Mid-1960s.jpg|thumb|120px|[[Frankie Avalon]] and [[Annette Funicello]] in publicity photo for [[Beach party film|the series]] of ''[[Beach Party]]'' films, 1963]]
During the 1950s, [[Joan Collins]] was prohibited by the [[censorship in the united states|censors]] from exposing her navel in ''[[Land of the Pharaohs]]'' (1955). To get around the censors' guidelines, she wore a jewel, a ruby, in her navel.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=DNptTqHKAYTAgQeEnqSJBg&ct=result&id=ZU3j3M8MAssC&dq=navel+censor&q=navel+#search_anchor |title=Three complete books |author=Joan Collins |publisher=Random House Value Publishing |year=1994 |isbn=9780517100745}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Joan Collins: The fastest lady in Hollywood|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-476428/Joan-Collins-The-fastest-lady-Hollywood.html|work=Daily Mail|accessdate=16 March 2012|date=20 August 2007|author=Graham Lord|location=London}}</ref> This technique of baring the midriff but gluing a jewel on the navel was used in many other Hollywood films featuring belly dance sequences.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shira.net/costuming/navel-jewel.htm |publisher=Dear Shira |title= A Jewel in the Navel? |quote=Many movies made in the U.S. and Europe between 1930 and 1970 portrayed 'Middle Eastern' women wearing garb that exposed their midriffs, with large jewels glued into their navels. |accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Elisabeth Bronfen|title=The knotted subject: hysteria and its discontents|year=1998|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn= 9780691012308|page=469|url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=_oljT-_QPNGrrAe-1dC8Bw&id=LNaakruoSJgC&dq=Elisabeth+Bronfen%2C+The+Knotted+Subject%3A+Hysteria+and+Its+Discontents.&ots=AnErt_5AMB&q=hollywood#v=snippet&q=hollywood&f=false}}</ref> [[Kim Novak]] wore a ruby in her navel for the film ''[[Jeanne Eagels (film)|Jeanne Eagels]]'' (1957); saying in an interview, "they had to glue it in every time. I got a terrible infection from it."<ref>{{cite news|title=Kim Novak: The Curves are Gem-studded|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qbUyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MuoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1978,1544100&dq=actress+navel&hl=en|accessdate=17 March 2012|newspaper=The Miami News|date=20 May 1964}}</ref> [[Marilyn Monroe]], for a scene from ''[[Some Like It Hot]]'' (1959), wore a dress that revealed skin everywhere but had a tiny piece of fabric to hide her navel.<ref>{{cite web|title=The World's Belly Button|url=http://www.vogue.it/en/beauty/beauty-in-vogue/01/06/stars-and-belly-button|work=Vogue Italia|accessdate=19 February 2012}}</ref> (The film was condemned by the National Legion of Decency, but for other reasons.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Phillips|first1=Gene|title=Some Like it Wilder|publisher=University of Kentucky Press|pages=223|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5uohNoRFkwIC&pg=PT270&lpg=PT270&dq=legion+of+decency+some+like+it+hot&source=bl&ots=rQfVMs8heo&sig=5zKrjrdJ8HwT4xn2_XBD5_oXZqU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HawQVOmxB4-byASZmoCwDg&ved=0CE0Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=legion%20of%20decency%20some%20like%20it%20hot&f=false}}</ref><ref name="NLDList">[http://www.listal.com/list/films-condemned-legion-decency Films Condemned by the Legion of Decency]</ref>)
By the 1960s, community standards had changed. Marilyn Monroe was allowed to expose her navel in ''[[Something's Got to Give]]'' (1962) and later commented, "I guess the censors are willing to recognize that everybody has a navel."<ref>{{cite news|author=Bob Thomas|title=Mystique endears 30 years after death|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cSdZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CUcNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5273,3224419&dq=navel+reveal&hl=en|accessdate=20 April 2012|newspaper=The Union Democrat|date=24 July 1992}}</ref> [[Ursula Andress]], appearing as [[Honey Rider]] in the 1962 [[James Bond]] film, ''[[Dr. No (film)|Dr. No]]'', wore her iconic [[White bikini of Ursula Andress|white bikini]], which exposed her midriff and navel. However, when [[Annette Funicello]] was cast in her first beach movie ''[[Beach Party]]'' (1963), [[Walt Disney]], who held her contract, insisted that she only wear modest bathing suits and keep her navel covered, to preserve her wholesome persona, though she was the only one of the ample number of young women in the film not bikini-clad.<ref>{{cite web | title=The Myth of the Hidden Navel | url=http://www.beachpartymoviemusic.com/TheMythoftheHiddenNavel.html | accessdate=20 February 2012 | publisher=Beachpartymoviemusic.com | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140103012357/http://www.beachpartymoviemusic.com/themythofthehiddennavel.html# | archive-date=3 January 2014 | dead-url=yes | df=dmy-all }}</ref> In the 1967 film ''[[Follow That Camel]]'', actress [[Anita Harris]] wore a jewel on her navel for a belly dance sequence.<ref>{{cite news|author=Lenika Cruz|title=Taylor Swift and the Fraught History of Navel-Gazing|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2015/01/taylor-swift-and-the-fraught-history-of-navel-gazing/384811/|accessdate=7 February 2015|work=The Atlantic|date=26 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Should You Believe?|url=http://www.shira.net/costuming/costuming-fact-or-fiction.htm|website=Shira.net|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
The Hays Code was abandoned soon after, and with it the prohibition of female navel exposure, as well as other restrictions. The influence of the National Legion of Decency had also waned by the 1960s. With the withdrawal of the Code and the change to a classification regime, the ban on the exposure of parts of the human body that had previously been regarded as immodest or indecent was withdrawn; and with it there was an increasing level of body exposure over time. The exposure of the navel ceased to be controversial in the context of a general increase in nudity.
During the late 1980s, [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]]'s heroines began exposing more skin as well. In the 1989 animated film ''[[The Little Mermaid (1989 film)|The Little Mermaid]]'', the animated lead protagonist, [[Ariel (Disney)|Ariel]], flashed her navel while wearing only fins and seashells, a first in Disney's history.<ref>{{cite news |author=Deborah Bradley |agency=Dallas Morning News |title=Disney animators give Pocahantas the sexiest cartoon image ever |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DyJVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hDsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3796,2488695&dq=navel+sexuality&hl=en |newspaper=Beaver County Times |location=Beaver, Pennsylvania |date=12 July 1995 |quote=And in 1989's "The Little Mermaid," rebellious teenager Ariel flashed her navel (a Disney first) wearing little more than fins, a couple of seashells, and some cleavage. |accessdate=9 December 2015}}</ref>
===Television=== [[File:I dream of jeannie hagman eden.JPG|thumb|left|[[Barbara Eden]] in a publicity photo of 1960's TV show ''[[I Dream of Jeannie]]'']] In 1951, the United States [[Code of Practices for Television Broadcasters]] came into force, which, besides other things, prohibited female navel exposure on US television.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jerry Della Femina|title=From Those Wonderful Folks Who Gave You Pearl Harbor: Front-Line Dispatches from the Advertising War|date=2010|publisher=Canongate Books|isbn=1847679684|page=201|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AQOh5UnMwZUC&pg=PA201&dq=belly+button&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_A_NVPOSMsXMmAXHn4CACQ&ved=0CCIQ6AEwATgy#v=onepage&q=belly%20button&f=false|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref> During the 1960s, [[Barbara Eden]] was not allowed to show her navel on the US TV show ''[[I Dream of Jeannie]]'' (1965–70).<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0RDhsKvlivcC&pg=PA80&dq=barbara+eden+navel&hl=en&ei=ndhtTuWHLYiugQffstGIBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepageq=barbara%20eden%20navel&f=false |title=I Watch, Therefore I Am: From Socrates to Sartre, the Great Mysteries of Life as Explained Through Howdy Doody, Marcia Brady, Homer Simpson, Don Draper, and Other TV Icons |author=Gregory Bergman |author2=Peter Archer |year=2011 |publisher=Adams Media |page=80 |isbn=9781440512414 |quote=Network executives got around the censors on the first issue by pointing out that Jeannie slept in a bottle and not on Tony's bed. On the second issue, they had to agree never to show Barbara Eden's navel during the show.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=29NFXftXwI8C&pg=PA201&dq=barbara+eden+navel&hl=en&ei=ndhtTuWHLYiugQffstGIBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false |title=Censoring sex: a historical journey through American media |author=John E. Semonche |year=2007 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |page=201 |isbn=9780742551329 |quote=In 1965 when the situation comedy ''I Dream of Jeannie'' premiered, the network censor barred showing of Barbara Eden's navel in her genie costume.}}</ref> Her pants had to be worn above the navel, which became ineffective. After a few frames of her navel exposure went unnoticed, they decided to use fabric and skin-colored make-up to cover her navel.<ref>{{cite web|title=11 Great Milestones in Televised Nudity|url=http://www.nerve.com/entertainment/great-moments-in-televised-nudity?page=2|publisher=Nerve.com|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> Her costume became low rise (with no censorship) [[I Dream of Jeannie... Fifteen Years Later|in 1985]]<ref>{{cite book |author=David Hofstede |title=What Were They Thinking? The 100 Dumbest Events In Television History |publisher=Back Stage Books |year=2004 |isbn=9780823084418 |page=100 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3i1HGbyT85MC&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100&dq=male+navel+restrictions&source=bl&ots=WYI7EwLXWh&sig=wYXj6Rcku_wQhNOQgNBd9llaa2I&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjelruq19HJAhVC4D4KHSsaDh8Q6AEINTAF#v=onepage&q=male%20navel%20restrictions&f=false}}</ref> and In 2013, Barbara Eden attended the [[Life Ball]] event in [[Vienna]] dressed in the same costume of ''I Dream of Jeannie'' but flaunting her navel.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ellie Krupnick|title='I Dream of Jeannie' Costume Re-Worn By Barbara Eden, 78|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/27/i-dream-of-jeannie-costume_n_3341519.html|accessdate=11 August 2013|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=29 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Adam Edelman|title=Barbara Eden, 78, dons iconic 'I Dream of Jeannie' costume onstage at Life Ball in Vienna|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/dream-jeannie-actress-plays-fight-aids-wink-nod-article-1.1355087|accessdate=11 August 2013|newspaper=Daily News|date=26 May 2013|location=New York}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Alison Schwartz|title=Barbara Eden Digs Up Jeannie Costume, Hangs with Bill Clinton|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20703758,00.html|accessdate=11 August 2013|newspaper=People|date=26 May 2013}}</ref> In February 1964, [[Scandinavian Airlines]] placed an advertisement in newspapers and magazines throughout America. It featured a bikini-clad blonde model exposing her bellybutton posing on a rock above the caption "What to show your wife in Scandinavia". The image that appeared in most publications had the belly button removed.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Vanishing Belly Button, 1964|url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/photo_database/image/the_vanishing_belly_button|publisher=The Museum of Hoaxes|accessdate=19 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Censorship: Out, Damned Spot! |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,938469,00.html |accessdate=19 October 2013 |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=6 March 1964}}</ref>
[[File:Sonny & Cher Show 1977.JPG|thumb|[[Cher]] exposing her navel for a scene from an Egyptian soap opera skit on ''[[The Sonny and Cher Show]]'', 1977]] The first exposure of a navel in a TV series occurred in 1961 on the [[Dr. Kildare (TV series)|''Dr. Kildare'' series]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Marcel Danesi|title=Dictionary of Media and Communications|url=http://npu.edu.ua/!e-book/book/djvu/A/iif_kgpm_Dictionary_of_Media.pdf|accessdate=24 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Marcel Danesi|title=Of Cigarettes, High Heels, and Other Interesting Things: An Introduction to Semiotics|date=30 April 2016|publisher=Springer|isbn=0230612784|page=205|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NFwYDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA205&lpg=PA205&dq=dr+kildare+navel&source=bl&ots=W3bRBRGjvB&sig=XztwpoXuKnmbrehZ2VgWteAB2Cs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwit6OeF4IDQAhXDQY8KHUHcDvQQ6AEIRTAJ#v=onepage&q=dr%20kildare%20navel&f=false|accessdate=24 March 2017}}</ref> [[Dawn Wells]] and [[Tina Louise]] were not allowed to expose their navels in ''[[Gilligan's Island]]'' (1964–67).<ref>{{cite web|author=Brian Wallace|title=The Liberalization of Television Programming [Infographic]|url=http://www.business2community.com/infographics/the-liberalization-of-television-programming-infographic-0497321|publisher=Business2Community.com|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> Wells was required to wear [[High-rise (fashion)|high-waisted]] shorts that covered her navel.<ref>{{cite web|author=Nojan Aminosharei|title=Televisionaries|url=http://www.elle.com/pop-culture/reviews/televisionaries-521457#slide-1|work=Elle|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=11 Great Milestones in Televised Nudity|url=http://www.nerve.com/entertainment/great-moments-in-televised-nudity|publisher=Nerve.com|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> Wells stated in an interview, "Oh my goodness, I designed the shorts. Because it was the first short shorts ever on television and it had to cover my navel. ''Gilligan's Island'' actually gave censors headaches back in the '60s. [[Ginger Grant|Ginger]]'s cleavage, and [[Mary Ann Summers|Mary Ann]]'s navel were only allowed 3 seconds an episode."<ref>{{cite web|title=Gilligan's Island's 'Mary Ann' has PNW connections|url=http://www.king5.com/story/entertainment/television/programs/evening-magazine/2015/01/16/gilligans-island-mary-ann-pnw/21715893/|website=king5.com|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> The censors missed [[Nichelle Nichols]] showing her navel in the second-season ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' episode "[[Mirror, Mirror (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Mirror, Mirror]]" (1967).<ref>{{cite web|title=Star Trek: The Original Series - Season 2 (1967)|url=http://www.grouchoreviews.com/reviews/3563|publisher=GrouchoReviews.com|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> It is believed that it was due to [[Bjo Trimble]] that it went unnoticed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hobnobbing with the Trimbles|url=http://www.wunderland.com/WhatsOld/2006/WN.11.16.06.html|publisher=Wunderland.com WebZine|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> Another episode of ''Star Trek'', called "[[A Private Little War]]" (1968), also managed to get past the censors when [[Nancy Kovack]]'s belly button was clearly visible in some shots and not covered by jewelry as seen when the fringe from her top was not covering it. In 1969, [[Mariette Hartley]] was not allowed to show her belly button in "[[All Our Yesterdays (Star Trek: The Original Series)|All Our Yesterdays]]" (1969), the penultimate episode of [[Gene Roddenberry]]'s ''Star Trek''. Gene had Mariette expose not one but two belly buttons in the [[sci-fi]] film ''[[Genesis II (film)|Genesis II]]'' (1973).<ref>{{cite web |author=Charlie Jane Anders |url=http://io9.com/5373050/a-sexy-lady-with-two-navels-shows-dylan-hunt-her-agonizer |title=A Sexy Lady With Two Navels Shows Dylan Hunt Her Agonizer |publisher=Io9.com |date=2 October 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.bookmice.net/darkchilde/hartley/hart2.html Mariette Hartley's Playboy Interview]. Bookmice.net. originally {{cite news |title=Mariette Hartley |date=August 1982 |work=Playboy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://corsinet.com/trivia/e-triv.html |title=Trivia about entertainment |publisher=Corsinet.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.startrek.com/article/mariette-hartley-cherishes-all-our-yesterdays |title=Mariette Hartley Cherishes "All Our Yesterdays" |publisher=Startrek.com |date=2 November 2011}}</ref>
In ''[[The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour]]'' (1971–74),<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9feBCLNhcFQC&pg=PA200&dq=sonny+cher+navel&hl=en&ei=keNtTtPJF6H00gHV-KjYBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=belly&f=false |title=The 1970s |author=Kelly Boyer Sagert |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |date=2007 |page=200 |isbn=9780313339196}}</ref> network censors feared [[Cher]]'s navel exposure would become a [[cause célèbre]] at [[CBS]].<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=MuNtTsPUAojt0gGyoeGaBQ&ct=result&id=vRUKAQAAMAAJ&dq=sonny+cher+navel&q=navel#search_anchor |title=Lillian Roxon's Rock encyclopedia |author=Lillian Roxon |publisher=Grosset & Grosset & Dunlap |year=1978 |page=466 |isbn=9780448145723}}</ref> Cher once commented, "There were so many things that were censored—ideas and words. All I know is I got in trouble for showing my belly button, and every time I turned around after I went off the air, all you saw were Cheryl Ladd's boobs."<ref>{{cite web|title=The many mutations of The Sonny and Cher shows|url=http://www.tvparty.com/sonnycher3.html|publisher=TVparty|accessdate=12 March 2012}}</ref> ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine dubbed Cher "Pioneer of the Belly Beautiful".<ref name="bb">{{cite news |title=Bare navels back in fashion |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ygYqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gRIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2326,5459060&dq=actress+navel&hl=en |newspaper=The Milwaukee Sentinel |date=14 April 1986 |page=2 |accessdate=17 March 2012}}</ref>
The American code of practice was suspended in 1983.<ref>Associated Press. "Broadcasters Decide to Dissolve Their Radio-TV Advertising Codes". ''The Miami Herald'', 6 January 1983, 19A. NewsBank. Web. 22 February 2013.</ref><ref>Collins, Bill. "Changes Are Few in TV Ads". ''The Philadelphia Inquirer''. 24 February 1983: C08. NewsBank. Web. 22 February 2013.</ref><ref>[http://encyclopedia.jrank.org/articles/pages/6439/Broadcasting-Self-Regulation-of.html Broadcasting, Self-Regulation of - The National Association of Broadcasters Codes of Practices, Broadcast Standards and Practices], JRank Articles</ref>
===Entertainment=== [[File:InThisLifeUnderGround.jpg|thumb|left|180px|[[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] performing in 1993]]
====1980s==== Navel exposure became common in the culture of [[20th-century music]], starting in the 1980s, with many famous female pop stars<ref>{{cite web|author=Erin Mayer|title=Can You Guess Which '90s Pop Star These Belly Button Rings Belong To?|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/35110-can-you-guess-which-90s-pop-star-these-belly-button-rings-belong-to|website=Bustle.com|accessdate=14 August 2014}}</ref> having appeared on and offstage and in music videos with their midriff exposed, usually wearing a [[crop top]], including [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], during 1983, she caused controversy when she wore a mesh crop top in her video for the song "[[Lucky Star (Madonna song)|Lucky Star]]". ''People'' magazine wrote that Madonna made the bare navel her trademark.<ref name="bb"/>
Actress [[Cher]] sported an Indian princess outfit with feathers and beads around her navel for the [[Academy Award]]s ceremony in 1986. [[California]] designer Christine Albers commented, "the look is good for anyone who has a great body but especially for women who do a lot of stomach exercises."<ref>{{cite news|title=Bellybutton comeback|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6tU0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=7VEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6269,1303369&dq=actress+navel&hl=en|accessdate=17 March 2012|newspaper=The Bryan Times|date=14 April 1986}}</ref>
[[Paula Abdul]]'s bellybutton was exposed in a [[fishnet]] [[See-through clothing|see-through dress]] in the 1989 music video for "[[Cold Hearted]]"<ref>{{cite web|title=Paula Abdul Cold Hearted Pop song from 1989|url=http://bestsongsever.com/paula-abdul/cold-hearted|website=bestsongsever.com|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> and she appeared with a [[tattooed]] navel in the music video for "[[My Love Is for Real]]" in 1995.<ref>{{cite news |author=David Bianculli |title=Michael Jackson's Not The Only Rock Veteran With A New Video |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-06-24/entertainment/9506240187_1_jean-baptiste-mondino-new-videos-entire-video |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |agency=New York Daily News |date=24 June 1995 |accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Britney Spears.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Britney Spears]] performing in 2003]]
====1990s and 2000s==== During the early 1990s, Canadian country singer [[Shania Twain]] appeared in low jeans baring her midriff and navel in her music videos and performances.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Sh-levpCt-IC&pg=PA164&dq=shania+twain+belly+button&hl=en&ei=Y9NtTobhKK_I0AH1kf3SBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=belly%20button&f=false |title=Shania Twain – The Biography |author=Robin Eggar |publisher=Simon and Schuster |year=2010 |page=262 |isbn=9781451604542}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=JdFtTpalKK3G0AHu8aDmBA&ct=result&id=qOdLAAAAYAAJ&dq=shania+twain+navel&q=navel#search_anchor |title=Grammy Magazine|volume=17 |issue=1 |publisher=National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (U.S.) |page=21}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cun-ZSs2zjgC&pg=PA188&dq=shania+twain+navel&hl=en&ei=NNJtTomXB8nc0QGf-vSWBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDMQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=belly%20&f=false |title=Westward expansion |author=Sara E. Quay |page=188 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2002 |isbn=9780313312359}}</ref> It became both the most widely discussed body part in country music and her trademark.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PRavFA8l2FQC&pg=PA133&dq=shania+twain+navel&hl=en&ei=JdFtTpalKK3G0AHu8aDmBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false |title=Understanding popular music |author=Roy Shuker |publisher=Routledge |year=2001 |isbn=9780415235099|page=133}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?ei=itJtToXjNYTr0gGHsYGLBQ&ct=result&id=m98Qn6NS_XYC&dq=shania+twain+navel&q=belly#search_anchor |title=On Her Way – The Life and Music of Shania Twain |author=Barbara Hager |publisher=Berkley Boulevard |year=1998 |isbn=9780425164518 |page=64}}</ref> Shania once commented, "Someone said to me once, 'Well, if I had your belly-button I'd sell 8 million albums too.' But it takes a lot more than a belly-button to sell more than 8 million albums."<ref>{{cite book|author=Dallas Williams|title=Shania Twain: On My Way|date=1997|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=155022297X|pages=232|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EDP-b9YSET0C&pg=PA191&dq=belly+button&hl=en&sa=X&ei=KhHNVLe9CMe2mQWF3IGQBA&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBjhu#v=onepage&q=belly%20button&f=false|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> [[Jennifer Lopez]] is believed to have started the trend of exposing the navel on stage and red carpets.<ref>{{cite news |author=Sheryl McCarthy |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mDRUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tY4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2879,3803902&dq=navel+sexuality&hl=en |newspaper=Boca Raton News |title=Actresses show more than we need to know |agency=Newsday |date=24 September 2003}}</ref> It has been said [[Christina Aguilera]] has the most recognizable belly button in history.<ref>{{cite book|author=Mary Anne Donovan|title=Christina Aguilera: A Biography|date=2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=0313383189|page=47|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yl7ZLWT81NgC&pg=PA47&dq=belly+button&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ixLNVJ_vGsHKmAXwl4CAAQ&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCTjmAQ#v=onepage&q=belly%20button&f=false|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> ''People'' magazine stated, "The 19-year-old hotshot chanteuse behind '[[What a Girl Wants (Christina Aguilera song)|What a Girl Wants]]', once a Mouseketeer alongside [[Britney Spears]], can't quite pull off pop star flash without belly-flopping."<ref>{{cite news |title=Christina Aguilera|work=People|date=18 September 2000|volume=54|issue=12|page=132|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20132339,00.html|accessdate=1 February 2015}}</ref> In 2001, the editors of ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica|Britannica]]'' commissioned an article on Britney Spears that deconstructs her bare midriff. The article describes Miss Spears's navel as "a heated boundary between baby and babe".<ref>Uhlig, Robert. (10 February 2001) [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1321953/Britannica-Spears-at-No-1-as-internet-encyclopaedia-goes-for-pop.html "Britannica Spears at No 1 as internet encyclopaedia goes for pop"]. ''The Daily Telegraph''.</ref> She had been a major inspiration for the navel piercing trend.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hannah Orenstein|title=I Hated My Stomach Until I Pierced My Belly Button|url=http://www.seventeen.com/beauty/a42344/i-hated-my-stomach-until-i-pierced-my-belly-button/|accessdate=24 March 2017|work=Seventeen|date=18 August 2016}}</ref> ''[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]'' magazine chose Madonna's navel as its "most incredible" rock star body part for a September 2005 feature.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2005-08-23-spin-list_x.htm Madonna's navel tops 'Spin' list]. ''USA Today''. (23 August 2005).</ref><ref>[http://www.upi.com/Odd_News/2005/08/23/Spin-cites-Madonnas-navel/UPI-36601124842263/ "Spin cites Madonna's navel"]. UPI. (23 August 2005).</ref><ref>[http://www.azcentral.com/arizonarepublic/arizonaliving/articles/0824People0824.html?&wired "'Spin' picks star parts, loves Madonna's navel the most"]. ''The Arizona Republic''.{{dead link|date=December 2015}}</ref> Gregorio Luke, former director of the [[Museum of Latin American Art]] who conducted lectures about belly buttons, said, "The belly button has been a sign of beauty in goddesses as different as [[Astarte]], [[Venus (goddess)|Venus]] or [[Aphrodite]]. We ask which is more beautiful, the perfectly round belly button of [[Jane Fonda]] or [[Raquel Welch]]'s grain of coffee navel? Every star from Madonna to [[Shakira]] proudly displays their belly button."<ref>{{cite web|title=Long Beach Playhouse Presents "Belly Buttons," A new show by Gregorio Luke|url=http://www.everythinglongbeach.com/long-beach-playhouse-presents-belly-buttons/|publisher=Everything Long Beach|accessdate=9 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Amanda Parsons|title=The Bellybutton|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/2012-03-15/calendar/the-bellybutton/|accessdate=9 April 2012|newspaper=OC Weekly|date=15 March 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404031236/http://www.ocweekly.com/2012-03-15/calendar/the-bellybutton/#|archive-date=4 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
On the contrary, American columnist [[Kathleen Parker]] in an article about [[Katharine Hepburn]] once commented, "Young movie-going girls today don't have access to many in the mold of Katharine Hepburn. Instead by mall observations most are Britney wannabes—hip-hugged, tattooed, pierced and out there. The female navel has become the refrigerator man's continental divide. I hate to break it to you, oh future daughters-in-law, but everybody's got a belly button. Your inney- or outey-ness is not the stuff either of revelation or revolution."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PRdSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZTUNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3392,36303&dq=navel+sexuality&hl=en |newspaper=Times-Union |location=Warsaw, Indiana |date=1 July 2003 |author=Kathleen Parker |title=Hepburn Was A Classic Feminist |agency=Scripps Howard News Service}}</ref>
===Fashion=== Exposed midriff is associated with the [[crop top]], often in association with [[Low-rise (fashion)|low-rise clothing]]. Another way that the navel may be exposed is via a deep [[plunging neckline]] dress or top that drops below the natural waist line.
[[File:Hüfthose.jpg|thumb|right|upright|A woman wearing a [[cropped top]] and [[Low-rise (fashion)|low-rise]] pants that expose the midriff and navel]] Low-rise clothing started in the early 1990s, when the British magazine ''[[The Face (magazine)|The Face]]'' featured [[Kate Moss]] in [[low-rise jeans]] on its March 1993 issue cover.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ziUAAAAAMBAJ&dq=New+York+Magazine%E2%80%8E+Navel&source=gbs_navlinks_s |title=Navel Mauvers |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=10 May 1993 |page=26 |accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref> Models such as [[Gisele Bündchen]] frequently flash their midriffs.<ref name="articles.nydailynews.com">{{cite news |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2000-05-07/entertainment/18136533_1_tops-midriff-navel |title=Cropped tops = midriff mania = abs-olutely erotic |author=Esther Gross Kremer |newspaper=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]] |location=New York |date=7 May 2000 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616074613/http://articles.nydailynews.com/2000-05-07/entertainment/18136533_1_tops-midriff-navel |archivedate=16 June 2012}}</ref> In 1994, [[Art Cooper]], editor-in-chief of ''[[GQ]]'' magazine said that his big seller in 1994 was the February issue with [[Geena Davis]] on the cover, on which she wore an [[Armani]] suit opened at the hips to reveal her navel,<ref>{{cite web|title=GQ Magazine | location=United States | date=February 1994|url=http://magazine-covers.lucywho.com/gq-magazine-united-states-february-1994-magazine-cover-t2764079.html|publisher=LucyWho.com|accessdate=20 April 2012}}</ref> It sold about 400,000 copies. He stated, "Part of the success is the navel factor. I think the belly button is really an erogenous zone."<ref>{{cite news|title=Varga Girls back in the pages of Esquire|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iUEgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=N38EAAAAIBAJ&pg=2297,8008621&dq=navel+reveal&hl=en|accessdate=20 April 2012|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=14 December 1994}}</ref>
[[Navel piercing]]<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hRHUOxramGEC&dq=navel+ring+saree&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Designing Clothes: Culture and Organization of the Fashion Industry |author=Veronica Manlow |publisher=Transaction Publishers |year=2009 |page=53 |isbn=9781412810555 |accessdate=9 December 2015 |quote=Recently we've seen an emphasis in women's clothing on the hips and abdomen—low rise pants, halter tops, and even rings and jewels for the navel.}}<!-- assumes that navel rings require piercing --></ref> and navel [[tattoo]]s<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=if6_kBbJlCcC&pg=PA327&dq=drew+barrymore+navel+tattoo&hl=en&ei=1PVtTs7zJYHegQeBwY2tAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Rhetorics of Display |author=Lawrence J. Prelli |publisher=University of South Carolina Press |year=2006 |isbn=9781570036194 |page=327}}</ref> has become more common among young women. The trend of piercing or tattooing the navel became popular in the 1990s.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q6FI2czFz6MC&pg=PA224&dq=belly+button+fetish&hl=en&ei=8N3WTq_yOefz0gG83pnLDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q=belly%20button%20fetish&f=false |title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Clothing Through World History: 1801 to the present |author=Jill Condra |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=2008 |isbn=9780313336652 |page=224}}</ref> It is popular among middle-aged women.<ref>{{cite news|author=Cindy Sigler Dagnan|title=Guest column: What happened to modesty?|url=http://www.joplinglobe.com/editorial/x212148869/Guest-column-What-happened-to-modesty|accessdate=16 March 2012|newspaper=The Joplin Globe|date=16 August 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Neha Kaura|title=Piercings make a fashion statement|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-05-20/trends/31779032_1_piercings-navel-ring-trend|accessdate=25 May 2012|newspaper=The Times of India|date=20 May 2012}}</ref> Actress [[Drew Barrymore]] has a butterfly tattoo beneath her navel.<ref>{{cite news|author=Cristina Gibson|title=Which Celeb Has a Butterfly on Her Belly?|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/196942/which-celeb-has-a-butterfly-on-her-belly|accessdate=11 August 2013|newspaper=E! Online|date=24 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-uxC5penpMEC&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Before you put that on: 365 daily style tips for her |author=Lloyd Boston |publisher=Simon and Schuster |year=2010 |isbn=9781451628722 |page=155}}</ref> The growing popularity of [[Belly dance|belly dancing]], where navel exposure is typical, has also added to the navel exposure trend.<ref>{{cite news |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ziUAAAAAMBAJ&q=belly+dancing#v=snippet&q=belly%20dancing&f=false |accessdate=8 December 2015 |date=10 May 1993 |title=Navel Maneuvers |author=Rebecca Mead |page=26 |issn=0028-7369}}</ref>
Contrarily, advice columnist [[Ann Landers]] commented, "Navels are neither sexy nor obscene. I do not believe any female of good taste would wear an outfit where her navel shows. This does not include women in costumes or those on beaches in bikinis. The same goes for males. An adult male who wears [[hip-huggers]] so low rates zero minus 10 on the scale of taste—it's my opinion but it's one I feel strongly about."<ref>{{cite news |title=Navel attraction questioned |author=Ann Landers |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1454&dat=19780624&id=x7ksAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NhMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5291,4563046 |newspaper=Star-News |location=Washington |date=24 June 1978}}. Google News.com (24 June 1978).</ref> Fashion historian [[James Laver]] told that he hasn't quite caught up with the idea of exposing the navel, saying, "I have never regarded that as a particularly attractive part of the human anatomy".<ref>{{cite news|author=Kim Blair|title=Fashion Historian claims skirts shouldn't go higher|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ImlkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=13wNAAAAIBAJ&pg=922,448503&dq=navel+expose&hl=en|accessdate=15 March 2012|newspaper=The Calgary Herald|date=2 March 1966}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Kim Blair|title=Tights and Tunics due if skirts go shorter|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RmtWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4OgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4735,955890&dq=navel+expose&hl=en|accessdate=15 March 2012|newspaper=The Spokesman-Review|date=4 March 1966}}</ref> The navel fashion returned in the 1980s, when a New York City ban on exposing the navel in public was lifted.<ref name="news" />
The importance of the navel is such that for Czech model [[Karolína Kurková]], who does not have a navel, the magazine and catalogue art directors routinely airbrush one in for her during post-production. They keep a collection of belly button shots in different positions, and Photoshop them on to her whenever she's doing a bikini picture.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1086567/Victorias-Secret-model-Karolina-Kurkova-riddle-missing-belly-button.html Victoria's Secret model Karolina Kurkova and the riddle of her missing belly button]. ''Daily Mail''. (17 November 2008).</ref> [[Kelly Ripa]] has also appeared in magazine covers of [[Shape (magazine)|Shape]] with morphed navels.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kelly Ripa's incredible morphing belly button|url=http://www.celebitchy.com/14551/kelly_ripas_incredibly_changed_belly_button/|publisher=Celebitchy|accessdate=18 February 2012}}</ref>
Since 2010, the crop top evolved by which women started wearing it with a [[High-rise (fashion)|high-rise]] skirts, jeans, or shorts that are high enough to cover the belly button.<ref>{{cite news|author=Brooke Brown|title=Crop tops return in a modest fashion|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/blog/70/10011908/Saving-style-Crop-tops-return-in-a-modest-fashion.html|accessdate=16 March 2012|newspaper=Deseret News|date=16 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816163217/http://www.deseretnews.com/blog/70/10011908/Saving-style-Crop-tops-return-in-a-modest-fashion.html#|archive-date=16 August 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Tania Braukämper|title=5 picks: retro-inspired crop tops|url=http://www.fashionising.com/clothing/b--5-retro-inspired-bralets-22537.html|publisher=Fashionising.com|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Noelle Talmon|title=Celebrity Style Watch: Belly Baring Crop Tops|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Noelle_Talmon/2012/04/07/celebrity_style_watch_belly_baring_cro|publisher=Star Pulse|accessdate=8 April 2012}}</ref> The [[bandeau]] top also made an appearance in formal wear, usually associated with a high-rise skirt or pants that cover the navel. Actress [[Halle Berry]] wore a bandeau with matching pants to the [[MTV Video Music Award]], fueling the trend of wearing a bandeau top as an out-of-home dress.<ref>[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SJ&s_site=mercurynews&p_multi=SJ&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EF3D12ADCEAD559&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM "Heat relief, what suits are hot – from tops to bottoms"], ''San Jose Mercury News'', page 1E, 8 June 2001</ref> [[Miley Cyrus]] also wore a bandeau top with cropped high waisted pants at the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]]<ref>{{cite news |author=Stephanie Webber |work=Us Weekly |date=24 August 2014 |url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-style/news/miley-cyrus-arrives-2014248 |title=Miley Cyrus Looks Sophisticated, Wears Black Bandeau and Leather Pants One Year After 2013 VMAs}}</ref> and [[Jourdan Dunn]] wore a bandeau top with a long skirt.<ref>''Daily Mail'', 24 August 2014: [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2733654/Jourdan-Dunn-crops-abs-revealing-bandeau-MTV-VMAs-help-checking-Amber-Roses-curvy-derriere.html Jourdan Dunn is top of the crops in abs revealing bandeau top at MTV VMAs... but she can't help checking out Amber Rose's curvy derriere]</ref>
===Sportswear=== ====Swimwear==== [[File:Ivet Lalova by Augustas Didzgalvis.jpg|thumb|250px|Bulgarian sprinter [[Ivet Lalova]] in a [[Bikini#Sports bikini|sports bikini]] with her navel tattoo]] {{see also|History of the bikini}} Displays of the female navel commenced with the introduction of the [[bikini]] in 1946, designed by [[Louis Réard]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.glamoursurf.com/articles/article/4918259/114188.htm |title=The Evolution of the Two Piece Swimsuit |date=1 December 2008 |publisher=Glamoursurf Vintage Swimwear and Lingerie}}</ref> though two-piece swimsuits that exposed the midriff but covered the navel appeared in the 1930s. Réard could not find a model who would dare wear his brief design, so he hired [[Micheline Bernardini]], a 19-year old [[striptease|nude dancer]] from the [[Casino de Paris]], as his model.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.bikiniscience.com/chronology/1945-1950_SS/LR4601_S/LR4601.html |title = Michele Bernadini: The First Bikini |first = Judson |last = Rosebush |work = Bikini Science |accessdate = 17 September 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927084552/http://www.bikiniscience.com/chronology/1945-1950_SS/LR4601_S/LR4601.html |archivedate = 27 September 2007 |df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref>Emily Mitchell, [http://www.time.com/time/international/1996/960701/fashion.html "The Bikini Turns 50"], 1 July 1996, Volume 148, No. 1, ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''</ref> The uptake of the new-style swimsuit was very slow, and even then the bikini was not regarded as suitable clothing beyond the beach or pool. During the 1960s, [[Mary Quant]]'s designs featured exposed navels and bare midriffs.<ref>{{cite news|author=Nadeane Walker|title=Quant Fashions Don't Reveal Everything|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1hwrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6p8FAAAAIBAJ&pg=2095,4915935&dq=navel+reveal&hl=en|accessdate=20 April 2012|newspaper=Reading Eagle|date=21 October 1969}}</ref> Exposure of the male navel was limited well into the 1960s. The swimwear covered the lower abdomen and usually the navel. Occasionally the swimwear would be worn immediately below the navel. The swimwear evolved to longer legs and lower waist line. Male swimwear could not be worn above the navel nor below the knee in events of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA).<ref>{{cite web |author=Michael Popke |date=November 2009 |url=http://www.athleticbusiness.com/high-school/high-school-swimming-moves-forward-after-suit-ban.html |title=High School Swimming Moves Forward After Suit Ban |publisher=AthleticBusiness}}</ref>
====Sports bikinis==== [[File:Dallas-001216-N-1110A-513.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Cheerleading]] outfits of [[Dallas Cowboy Cheerleaders]]]] Bikinis have become a major component of marketing various women's sports,<ref name="Kilborn">Laura Grae Kilborn, "[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DP&p_theme=dp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF44E9A0508C03&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM The Marketing Of Female Athletes]", ''The Denver Post'', 11 August 1998</ref> and most female [[Athletics (sport)|athlete]]s often wear a [[Bikini#Sports bikini|sports bikini]] that exposes the navel as the professional attire. Bulgarian athlete [[Ivet Lalova]] is known for her "tribal sun" tattoo around her navel.<ref> *{{cite news |title=Olympic fashion in Beijing |url=https://www.ajc.com/sports/olympic-fashion-beijing/xUfV0cNI6G0Fs1vOTIqWxK/#2 |accessdate=11 February 2015|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution}} *{{cite news|title=Latest revealing sporting ink|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/sport/image-gallery/d4f73dcfe3c30ac093178236db1c558a?page=2&nk=d30fd7a9cf490726f685b0255dca2c41|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Daily Telegraph}} *{{cite news |author=Paul Martella|title=Olympic crush: Ivet Lalova|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/fourth-place-medal/olympic-crush-ivet-lalova-214140503--oly.html|website=Yahoo.com|accessdate=11 February 2015}} *{{cite web |author1=Sam Quinn |title=Ivet Lalova: Everything You Need to Know About 28-Year-Old Bulgarian Olympian |url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1286117-ivet-lalova-everything-you-need-to-know-about-28-year-old-bulgarian-olympian |publisher=Bleacher Report |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120808234309/http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1286117-ivet-lalova-everything-you-need-to-know-about-28-year-old-bulgarian-olympian |archivedate=August 8, 2012 |date=August 5, 2012}}</ref> Croatian athlete [[Blanka Vlašić]] is famous for her navel piercing.<ref>{{cite news|title=Beauties of Olympics|url=http://www.esteticamagazine.co.uk/ukolympics/item/468-beauties-of-olympics|accessdate=15 May 2015|publisher=Estetica Magazine|date=24 July 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=How female high-jumpers raised the fashion bar|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2010/aug/02/high-jump-fashion|accessdate=15 May 2015|newspaper=The Guardian|date=2 August 2010}}</ref>
====Cheerleading==== The fashion later became increasingly popular through sporting styles tops comprising modified [[sports bra]]s without additional outer garments, [[Bikini#Sports bikini|sports bikinis]], and [[cheerleading]] style fashions developing largely from the styles originating with the [[Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders]] in the early 1970s.<ref>{{cite book|author=Tim Delaney |author2=Tim Madigan|title=Sports: Why People Love Them!|year=2009|publisher=University Press of America|isbn= 9780761844891|page=248|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_leJMTGB3OoC&pg=PA148&dq=cheerleader+midriff&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_wyAT--XCoTprQeL5NTrBQ&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=midriff&f=false}}</ref>
====Tennis==== Female tennis players are known for exposing their navels or navel piercings on court.<ref> *{{cite news |last1=Jones |first1=Chris |title=Queen of Diamonds Sets a Tummy Trend|url=https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1G1-96251549/queen-of-diamonds-sets-a-tummy-trend |newspaper=The Evening Standard |accessdate=11 February 2015}} *{{cite web|author=Lindsay|title=#NeverForget Dinara Safina: A Modern Fairytale|url=http://www.changeovertennis.com/neverforget-dinara-safina-a-modern-fairytale/|website=changeovertennis.com|accessdate=11 February 2015}} *{{cite news|author=Charles Bricker|title=Capriati Wins On Day 1|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2004-08-31/sports/0408310296_1_jennifer-capriati-opening-set-outfit|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=31 August 2004}} *{{cite news|author=Steve Wilstein|title=U.S Open features teen revolution|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1696&dat=19970831&id=av0cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GJgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6710,3540509|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=Daily News|date=31 August 1997}}</ref> American tennis player [[Serena Williams]] was noted by the media for exposing her navel piercing during her matches.<ref>{{cite news|author=Nick McCarvel|title=9 of the best Serena Williams-Maria Sharapova matches|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/tennis/2015/01/30/serena-williams-maria-sharapova-memorable-matches/22561567/|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=USA Today|date=30 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Ron Dicker|title=TENNIS; Williams Advances With Style|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/26/sports/tennis-williams-advances-with-style.html|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=The New York Times|date=26 May 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Venus and Serena Williams in pictures: their outrageous tennis outfits through the years|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/picturegalleries/8268556/Venus-and-Serena-Williams-in-pictures-their-outrageous-tennis-outfits-through-the-years.html?image=16|accessdate=11 February 2015|work=The Telegraph}}</ref> Similarly, retired Russian tennis player [[Anna Kournikova]] was known for frequent navel exposure during her matches.<ref>{{cite news|title=Weeb Ewbank: A Man of His Era(s)|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/1998-12-01/news/weeb-ewbank-a-man-of-his-era-s/full/|accessdate=7 February 2015|work=The Village Voice News|date=1 December 1998}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Jeff Merron|title=Hey, have you seen Anna?|url=http://espn.go.com/page2/s/merron/030509.html|accessdate=7 February 2015|work=ESPN}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=David Whitley|title=Sex Sells, And Anna Sure Knows How To Make Guys Enjoy Tennis|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2001-12-15/sports/0112150340_1_anna-kournikova-ice-palace-champ|accessdate=7 February 2015|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=15 December 2001}}</ref> In 2009, for an interview to the German magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' when asked about her belly button showing during serves, she commented, "These are men's ravings.Why you should hide it, when it isn't necessary? Female beach volley ball players play in bikinis - does it bother anyone?"<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview for German magazine ''Der Spiegel'' in New York|url=http://www.anna4ever.com/more_variousinterviews_showvint.php?id=371|website=anna4ever.com|accessdate=7 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150208012331/http://www.anna4ever.com/more_variousinterviews_showvint.php?id=371#|archive-date=8 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> American female golfer [[Laura Diaz]] commenting to the [[LPGA|Ladies Professional Golf Association]] for ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', "The LPGA needs to acknowledge that a lot of people watch women's sports more for the women than for the sports. Why else would Anna Kournikova, who has never won a singles title, be the most popular player in women's tennis? We have quite a few attractive women, and we should use our looks to our advantage. After all, what's so wrong with seeing an occasional belly button?"<ref>{{cite news|author=Laura Diaz|title=My Shot To attract new fans, the LPGA should take a lesson from our past and sell sex appeal|url=https://www.si.com/vault/2001/09/03/309785/my-shot-to-attract-new-fans-the-lpga-should-take-a-lesson-from-our-past-and-sell-sex-appeal|accessdate=7 February 2015|work=Sports Illustrated|date=3 September 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Elizabeth Beggs|title=Tomboy: Sexuality in Women's Sport|date=2007|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=0549257020|page=18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lbUIYrrm3aMC&pg=PA18&dq=belly+button&hl=en&sa=X&ei=BRHNVMbIN6T5mAXp9IGABg&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBThk#v=onepage&q=belly%20button&f=false|accessdate=7 February 2015}}</ref>
====American football==== Males often wear no shirt with lower rise shorts during practice. This was somewhat upheld during practice of [[American football]], which was carried over to wearing [[crop top|cropped]] jerseys during 1980s telecasts. Cropped jerseys became dormant for 20 years until male athletes returned to midriff exposure<ref>{{cite news |author=Marissa Payne |date=29 August 2015 |title=Ohio State's Ezekiel Elliott wants to trademark 'hero in a half-shirt' |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/early-lead/wp/2015/08/29/ohio-states-ezekiel-elliott-wants-to-trademark-hero-in-a-half-shirt/}}</ref> for comfort purposes. However, the NCAA has placed an official ban on navel exposure.<ref> *{{cite web |author=Emily Van Buskirk |title=The NCAA Bans Belly Buttons, Prompting Players To Cry Foul |date=19 August 2015 |publisher=The Sports Fan Journal |url=http://www.thesportsfanjournal.com/sports/football/ncaa-bans-crop-top-jerseys-belly-buttons-ezekiel-elliott-myles-jack-daniel-lasco/}} *{{cite web
