|url=http://www.sportsmanias.com/news/oregon-ducks/so-long-ncaa-crop-tops-ncaa-bans-jerseys-with-too-little-and-facemasks-with-too/54fe04e5f7ed2f09140000b7 |publisher=''The Oregonian'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117082002/http://www.oregonlive.com/ducks/index.ssf/2015/03/so_long_college_football_crop-.html |archivedate=November 17, 2015 |date=March 9, 2015}} *{{cite news |title=Crop-Top Jerseys Banned |date=11 March 2015 |publisher=College Spots Business News |url=http://collegesportsbusinessnews.com/issue/february-2015/article/crop-top-jerseys-banned}} *{{cite news |author=Jasmine Watkins |title=NCAA bans football players from wearing rolled-up jerseys |date=8 March 2015 |publisher=SportingNews |url=http://www.sportingnews.com/ncaa-football-news/4637960-ncaa-crop-top-rolled-up-jersey-ohio-state-ezekiel-elliott}} *{{cite news |author=Avery Stone |date=2 April 2015 |title=Ezekiel Elliott says NCAA rule banning crop tops is 'silly' |newspaper=USA Today |url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2015/04/ezekiel-elliott-says-ncaa-rule-banning-crop-tops-is-silly}} *{{cite news |agency=SI Wire |date=9 March 2015 |title=NCAA bans players from showing abs in games |publisher=SI.com |url=https://www.si.com/college-football/2015/03/09/ncaa-bans-players-showing-abs-games}} *{{cite news |author=Austin Ward |date=2 April 2015 |title=Ezekiel Elliott scoffs at jersey rule |publisher=ESPN |url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/12605826/ezekiel-elliott-ohio-state-buckeyes-says-crop-top-jersey-rule-silly}} *{{cite news |author=Graham Watson |date=9 March 2015 |title=NCAA rule bans players from wearing cropped jerseys in games |publisher=Yahoo Sports |url=https://sports.yahoo.com/blogs/ncaaf-dr-saturday/ncaa-rule-bans-players-from-wearing-cropped-jerseys-during-games-162014010.html}} *{{cite news |author=Glen Erby |date=8 March 2015 |title=NCAA Bans Ezekiel Elliott Style Tucked Under Jerseys |publisher=Black Sports Online |url=http://blacksportsonline.com/home/2015/03/ncaa-bans-ezekiel-elliott-style-tucked-under-jerseys/}}</ref> The [[National Football League]] has long placed a ban on navel exposure (It has since required jerseys to be tucked in.) and banned [[ Ezekiel Elliott |Elliott]]'s crop top in September 2016.
==Mediterranean, Hebrew and Middle Eastern cultures== ===Literature and philosophy=== [[File:BellyDancerMarrakech.jpg|thumb|A [[belly dance]]r in [[Marrakech]] in [[Morocco]] ]] The navel is mentioned as an important element of a woman's beauty in the [[Song of Songs]] of the [[Hebrew Bible]].<ref name="Murphy">Murphy Ronald E (1992) "Song of songs, Book of", in The Anchor Bible Dictionary, vol 6. p. 151</ref><ref name="Annotation">Dobbs-Allsopp F. W. (2001) Annotation and commentary on "Song of Solomon" in 'The New Oxford Annotated Bible' (with the Apocrypha. Third Edition (Ed) Coogan, M.D. Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2001. page 966 from pages 959–968</ref> It contains imagery similar to that in the love songs of [[ancient Egyptian literature]].<ref name="Murphy"/> Song of Songs 7:2 states, "Your navel is a rounded bowl."<ref name="NRSV">''The New Oxford Annotated Bible''. New Revised Standard Version. Oxford: Oxford University Press 2001.</ref> The verse preceding the line mentioning the navel (Song of Songs 7:1) states, "your rounded thighs are like jewels, the work of a master hand",<ref name="NRSV"/> ) and the verse following states, "Your belly is a heap of wheat."<ref name="NRSV"/> Thus, the description of the navel is placed textually in between the description of the curves of a woman through [[thigh]] and the [[stomach]] or [[midriff]].<ref name="Annotation"/> "Belly" also suggests the womb, and the combination of the imagery of the womb with that of wheat suggests the link between eroticism and fertility through the imagery of the navel and curvaceous thighs.<ref name="Annotation"/> These passages also celebrate a curvaceous stomach and midriff and plumpness as aspects of female [[physical attractiveness]].<ref name="Annotation"/>
In the ancient Mediterranean, [[Hebrew]], [[Israelites|Israelite]] and [[Middle Eastern]] [[worldview]], it was a common belief that shrines, important places such as cities or capitals, or other such places of prominence had a position of centrality to the world and hence equated to the child-bearing, life-giving navel of a mother.<ref name="Sperling">{{cite book |last=Sperling |first=D |year=1976 |chapter=Navel of the earth |title=The Interpreter's Dictionary of the Bible: An Illustrated Encyclopedia (Supplementary Volume) |editor=Keith Crim |editor2=Victor Paul Furnish |editor3=Lloyd Richard Bailey Sr. |display-editors = 3 |editor4=Emory Stevens Bucke |location=Nashville |publisher=Abingdon Press |pages=622–623 |isbn=978-0687192694}}</ref> These domains constituted what could be regarded as important [[Maternal bond|bond]] that linked the universe.<ref name="Sperling"/> Thus [[Nippur]], the ancient city of the [[Mesopotamian people]], was often described as the "navel".<ref name="Sperling"/> This suggested to the prominence of the location and the way it was seen to function as a place of centrality and as a link between earth and the heavens and the Universe.<ref name="Sperling"/> The [[Greeks]] thought that the conical stone ''[[Omphalos]]'' ("navel") located at [[Delphi]] was the center of the earth.<ref name="Sperling"/>
In a similar vein, in the [[Jewish]] ''[[Midrashim]]'' it is stated, "God created the world like an [[embryo]]. Just as the embryo begins at the navel and continues to grow from that point, so too the world. The Holy One, blessed be he, began the world from its navel. From there it was stretched hither and yon. Where is its navel? [[Jerusalem]]. And its (Jerusalem's) navel itself? The altar."<ref name="Sperling"/><ref>Jellinek, Beth ha-Midrash, V, 63{{Full citation needed|date=December 2015}}</ref> This passage describes how the centrality of the ancient city of Jerusalem and of the altar of the [[Temple of Jerusalem|ancient temple of Jerusalem]] within cosmic framework was equated to the navel of a mother and the source of life.<ref name="Sperling"/> This is also seen in the [[Book of Jubilees]] 8:19 and [[Book of Enoch]] 26:1 where it is describes [[Mount Zion]] as "The center of the navel of the earth".<ref name="Sperling"/> In [[Samaritan]] tradition [[Mount Gerizim]] is described as the navel of the earth, the only place that was not submerged in the [[Rain|deluge]] of the story of [[Noah's Ark]].<ref name="Sperling"/> The phrase "navel of the earth" is used in (Ezek 38:12; Judg 9:37) [[Aramaic]] ''tibbur'' ("navel") and is also mentioned in Ezek 16:4.<ref name="Sperling"/> According to Samaritan tradition, [[Adam]] was made from the dust of Mount Gerizim.<ref>{{cite book |author=Gaster T. H. |editor= George Arthur Buttrich |year=1962|chapter=Samaritans |title=The Interpreters Dictionary of the Bible |volume=4 |publisher=Abingdon Press |isbn=978-0687192731 |page=196}}</ref> The navel is also celebrated in the [[Belly dance|belly dancing]] tradition of Mediterranean, and middle eastern cultures.<ref name="Hobin">Hobin, Tina (2003) ''Belly Dance: The Dance of Mother Earth''. Marion Boyars Publishers Ltd. London. New York p. 173-195. {{ISBN|978-0714530918}}.</ref> When [[Pope Urban II]] called for the [[First Crusade]], he referred to Jerusalem as "[[axis mundi|the navel of the world]]".<ref>http://www1.cbn.com/spirituallife/calling-for-the-first-crusade</ref>
===Bans and controversies=== In Egypt, dancing in public with an uncovered navel is illegal, so many dancers wear a body stocking or netting to cover their skin.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jasminjahal.com/articles/98_07.html|title=BELLY DANCE EGYPTIAN STYLE|website=www.jasminjahal.com|access-date=10 May 2016}} {{dead link|date=August 2018}}</ref> An Egyptian girl named Rubi upset members of parliament and the TV authority enough to institute a ban on music videos when a woman's navel appears.<ref>{{cite web|author=Maria Golia|title=Meditations on the navel ban|url=http://www.nthposition.com/mediationsonthenavel.php|website=nthposition.com|accessdate=29 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402090450/http://www.nthposition.com/mediationsonthenavel.php#|archive-date=2 April 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Maria Golia|title=Culture Briefs|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2004/jul/20/20040720-115824-2913r/?page=all|accessdate=29 March 2015|work=The Washington Times|date=20 July 2004}}</ref>
==Indian culture== ===Ancient times=== [[File:Didarganj_Yakshi_statue_in_the_Bihar_Museum.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Didarganj Yakshi]], a sculpture of a woman in navel-exposing attire.]] While the West was relatively resistant to [[midriff]]-baring clothing until the 1980s, it has long been a fashion with Indian women.<ref name="Mukulika">Banerjee, Mukulika & Miller, Daniel (2003) ''The Sari''. Oxford; New York: Berg {{ISBN|1-85973-732-3}}</ref> These women, especially those from [[Southern India]], have traditionally worn [[sari]]s that bare the midriff.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Dr. A. Sahayadoss |author2=A. Saghayamary |title=Traditional Clothing of Dravidians with special reference to Arimuti |url=http://www.academia.edu/28952225/Traditional_Clothing_of_Dravidians_with_special_reference_to_Arimuti_Genital_Shield |quote=The author also dwells on the traditional way of wearing sari exposing stomach and the navel for both men and women of south India and its special significance.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Dressing the Indian woman through history |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-30330693 |publisher='''BBC News Magazine'' |date=6 December 2014 |quote=In southern India, even in colonial times, some women did not cover the upper part of their body.}}</ref> Women from [[Rajasthan]] leave the midriff exposed while wearing [[Gagra choli|Ghagra Cholis]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Lajpat Rai |edition=Third |year=2008 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W7c8TBQhoAIC&pg=PA148&dq=lehenga+saree&hl=en&ei=J1VjTvuNEZTUgAfvvuGsCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CGEQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Social Science a Textbook in History for Class IX as per New Syllabus |publisher=VK (India) Enterprises |page=148 <!-- |isbn=978-81-89611-16-X printed in book but invalid -->}}</ref> These women often cover their heads with ''[[dupatta]]s'',<ref>{{cite book |title=India: A Cross-curricular Theme |year=2010 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lsai4v554d8C&dq=lehenga+saree&q=lehenga+saree#v=onepage&q=lehenga%20&f=false |publisher=R.I.C. Publications |pages=42, 43 |isbn=9781741269116}}</ref> and may cover their faces in front of strangers with ''[[ghoonghat]]s''. There is a belief in India that navel-baring has a symbolic, almost mystical, association with birth and life, and that the display is meant to emphasize the centrality of nature in the nurture role.<ref name="Beck">Beck, Brenda (1976) "The Symbolic Merger of Body, Space, and Cosmos in Hindu Tamil Nadu" in ''Contributions to Indian Sociology''; 10(2): 213–43.</ref> In ancient Indian tradition, the navel of the god [[Vishnu]] is considered to be the center of the universe and the source of life.<ref name="WeidnerBridges2003">{{cite book|author1=Jay Weidner|author2=Vincent Bridges|title=The Mysteries of the Great Cross of Hendaye: Alchemy and the End of Time|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mRVAmMo9in8C&pg=PA297|date=10 December 2003|publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co|isbn=978-0-89281-084-0|pages=297–}}</ref> From his navel a new world emerges. This has been depicted in many ancient Indian sculptures as a lotus emerging from the navel on which god [[Brahma]] is seated.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=clUmKaWRFTkC&dq=indian+sculpture+Navel&q=navel+brahma#v=snippet&q=navel%20brahma&f=false |title=Indian Sculpture: Circa 500 B.C.-A.D. 700 |author=Los Angeles County Museum of Art |author2=Pratapaditya Pal |publisher=University of California Press |date=1986 |page=40}}.</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-fvKVDxcJoUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Indian+Sculpture:+700%E2%80%931800&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwisuNn22s_JAhVX2GMKHYrlDCsQ6AEILzAA#v=onepage&q=navel%20brahma&f=false |title=Indian Sculpture: 700–1800 |publisher=University of California Press |year=1988 |author=Los Angeles County Museum of Art |author2=Pratapaditya Pal |isbn=9780520064775 |pages=66, 101, 254}}</ref>
Although women in ancient India wore saris that bared the midriff, the ''[[Dharmasastra]]'' writers stated that women should be dressed such that the navel was never visible,<ref>{{cite book|author=Anant Sadashiv Altekar|title=The Position of Women in Hindu Civilization, From Prehistoric Times to the Present Day|year=1956|publisher=Motilal Banarsidass Publ|isbn= 9788120803244|page=380|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VYG4K0yYHQgC&pg=PA282&dq=navel+sari&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OR3AT5X4EMvprQf73_3VCQ&ved=0CF0Q6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false}}</ref> and navel exposure became taboo.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DoY-tEMgJ8UC&pg=PA434&dq=erotic+navel&hl=en&ei=_RvgTtSWO8Hf0QG8jomJBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false |title=Folkways: A Study of Mores, Manners, Customs and Morals |author=William Graham Sumner |publisher=Cosimo, Inc. |year=2007 |page=434 |isbn=9781602067585}}</ref> The trend of exposing the navel was started by women who were dancers, acrobats, or entertainers, and who developed a technique of wearing the sari like a pair of trousers well below the navel to assist in the free movement of the legs.<ref>{{cite book|author=Jyotsna Kamat |title=Social Life in Medieval Karnataka |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5CczZrHsc7EC |accessdate=11 June 2011 |date=1 February 1980 |publisher=Abhinav Publications |isbn=978-0-8364-0554-5}}</ref> Women in this type of attire are very common in many ancient Indian sculptures,<ref>{{cite web |author1=Alka Pande |title=Indian woman - an icon of fertility and abundance |url=https://www.indiatoday.in/magazine/cover-story/story/20110613-indian-woman-is-the-symbol-of-fertility-and-abundance-746330-2011-06-03 |publisher=''India Today Magazine'' |date=June 13, 2011}}</ref> and paintings.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_jRe-U3KiXIC&dq=navel+ring+saree&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Salabhanjika in Art Philosophy and Literature |publisher=Rajkamal Prakashan Pvt Ltd}}</ref>
Indian sculpture emphasised the centrality and sexuality that emanated from the depiction of the woman's navel. One of the most stunning examples would be [[Didarganj Yakshi]], a statue of a woman made during the [[Mauryan]] period. Carved out of [[sandstone]], which gives it a natural shine where the navel is deeply embedded within the centre of the torso, drawing the focus of the viewer.<ref>{{cite news|author=Alka Pande|title=The Art of the Matter Indian woman – an icon of fertility and abundance|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/indian-woman-is-the-symbol-of-fertility-and-abundance/1/140264.html|accessdate=8 March 2012|newspaper=IndiaToday|date=3 June 2011}}</ref> Before sculpting, the sculptors created an image and indicated the six structural centers, of which the navel is one, as defined by Yoga principles.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=09qUXlCkyVIC&pg=PA42&dq=erotic+navel&hl=en&ei=QGLgTrPlCMHl0QGO_-WcBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFcQ6AEwCDgy#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false |title=The Hindu Temple: Deification of Eroticism |author=Alain Daniélou |page=42 |publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co |year=2001 |isbn=9780892818549}}</ref> Technically, the typical female representation in ancient Indian art includes an [[Female body shape#Female shapes|hourglass figure]] with large [[hip]]s, [[breast]]s, and [[buttock]]s, and a deep navel.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ujeZuPyMNYEC&q=belly#v=snippet&q=navel%20hips&f=false |title=Medical literature from India, Sri Lanka and Tibet |chapter=The romarājǐ in India Kāvya and Āyurvedic literature |author=Rahul Peter Das |editor=Gerrit Jan Meulenbeld |publisher=E. J. Brill |year=1991 |isbn=9789004095229 |page=2}}</ref> According to Indian [[physiognomy]], if a woman's navel is deep, she is popular and loved by her husband. A broad, fleshy, shallow navel indicates a lucky woman. A woman with deep navel with a whirl to the right side is considered auspicious and is expected to lead a comfortable life.<ref>[http://www.aryabhatt.com/women/women3.htm Physiognomy Of Women]. Aryabhatt.com.</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ujeZuPyMNYEC&pg=PA21&dq=kama+navel&hl=en&ei=dQ_fTvX6LaTV0QH5-9jOBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFoQ6AEwCTgK#v=snippet&q=deep%20navel%20whirl%20right&f=false |title=Medical literature from India, Sri Lanka and Tibet |chapter=The romarājǐ in India Kāvya and Āyurvedic literature |author=Rahul Peter Das |editor=Gerrit Jan Meulenbeld |publisher=E. J. Brill |year=1991 |isbn=9789004095229 |page=6}}</ref> Famous Indian painter [[M. F. Husain]] once commented, "The belly button has always been in. It has been an intrinsic part of the Indian woman. It has been part of Indian sculptures that go back so many centuries. That is why so many years ago, even in the 50s, all my works had women show their belly buttons."<ref>[http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/hindi/article/17832.html "Navel-gazing, desi style!"]. Uma Nair, IANS. Indiaglitz.com (3 November 2005).</ref><ref>[http://www.glamsham.com/movies/scoops/05/nov/04naval.asp Navel-gazing, desi style!]. Glamsham.com.</ref><ref name="top 10 navels" />
===Recent times=== {{multiple image | align = right | image1 = Sherlyn Chopra at Playboy press meet 06.jpg | width1 = 200 | image2 = Anangsha Biswas 5.jpg | width2 = 200 | footer = <center>Indian actresses [[Sherlyn Chopra]] and Anangsha Biswas wearing [[sari]]s which exposes the midriff.</center> }}
With their migration to different countries, many Indian women began to wear the normal sari below the waistline, exposing the navel in a style known as a [[Low-rise (fashion)|low-rise]] or low hip sari.<ref>{{cite book|author=Brian M. Du Toit |title=Aging and menopause among Indian South African women |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9ukaQcdV9oC |accessdate=11 June 2011 |year=1990 |publisher=SUNY Press |isbn=978-0-7914-0390-7}}</ref><ref>[http://www.fancy-indian-saris.com/sari-below-navel.html Sari Below Navel – Enhance Your Beauty and Grace]. Fancy-indian-saris.com.</ref><ref>[http://www.fancy-indian-saris.com/saree-navel.html Style and Attraction – Saree Navel Dress]. Fancy-indian-saris.com.</ref> The trend started during the 1950s, when saris were worn below the navel, with big pleats that were tightly draped across the curves of the body.<ref>{{cite news|author=Aasha Mehreen Amin |author2=Kajalie Shehreen Islam |author3=Srabonti Narmeen Ali |title=Fashion Reincarnated, Recycled, Refined |url=http://www.thedailystar.net/magazine/2004/06/03/cover.htm|accessdate=13 April 2012|newspaper=Star Magazine|date=25 June 2004}}</ref> Due to [[liberalization]] and changing global markets, saris are re-emerging as erotic apparel.<ref>[http://www.fancy-indian-saris.com/sexy-saree.html A Sexy Saree – Get Daring and Trendy!!!]. Fancy-indian-saris.com.</ref><ref>[http://www.fancy-indian-saris.com/saree-hot.html What makes a saree hot?]. Fancy-indian-saris.com.</ref> As a result, saris began to be designed in innovative ways using different materials, such as transparent and semi-transparent saris made of [[sheer fabric]]s like [[chiffon (fabric)|chiffon]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Margaret Maynard |title=Dress and globalisation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bkWIHaI1mfsC |accessdate=11 June 2011 |year=2004 |publisher=Manchester University Press |isbn=978-0-7190-6389-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Jennifer Craik |title=The Face of Fashion: Cultural Studies in Fashion |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8m2FwzNSUl8C |accessdate=11 June 2011 |date=1 December 1993 |publisher=Taylor and Francis |isbn=978-0-203-40942-8}}</ref><ref>[http://www.fancy-indian-saris.com/transparent-saree.html Transparent Saree – Add Spice to Your Style!!]. Fancy-indian-saris.com.</ref> These modern saris may be draped in different ways,<ref>[http://www.utsavfashion.in/store/style.aspx?cid=1&styleid=83 Informal Saree Draping at Utsav Fashion]. Utsavfashion.in.</ref> such as a [[petticoat]] being tied about {{convert|10|to|13|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} below the navel, just above the pubic area, and a small blouse ending just below the [[breast]]s with a thin ''[[Sari|pallu]]'' exposing some part of the [[blouse]] and almost the entire midriff.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/27/opinion/27iht-eddatta.html Meanwhile: Unraveling the sari]. ''The New York Times''. (28 April 2005). Retrieved 11 June 2011.</ref> In September 2012, ''[[The New York Times]]'' featured a wedding announcement with an image of a woman of Indian heritage displaying her navel in a ''[[gagra choli]]'' for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|author=Patricia Zohn|title=A Tale of Two Brides|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/patricia-zohn/a-tale-of-two-brides_b_1949510.html|accessdate=13 October 2012 |publisher=The Huffington Post|date=9 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Veni Manickam and Vikram Thomas | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/30/fashion/weddings/veni-manickam-vikram-thomas-weddings.html | accessdate=13 October 2012 | newspaper=The New York Times | date=30 September 2012}}</ref> This style was popularised by [[Bollywood]] celebrities<ref>{{cite news|author=Ziya Us Salam|title=Sargam (1979)|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/friday-review/blast-from-the-past-column-sargam/article6594777.ece|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=The Hindu|date=13 November 2014}}</ref> and other popular regional film industries, such as [[Tamil cinema|Tamil]] and [[Cinema of Andhra Pradesh|Telugu cinema]].<ref name="southie">{{cite web|title=Things heroines do to stay in limelight?|url=http://southie.in/heroines-expose-to-be-in-limelight/|website=southie.in|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kona Cutting Samantha's Dresses|url=http://www.gulte.com/movienews/19088/Kona-Cutting-Samanthas-Dresses|website=Gulte.com|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kona behind Samantha Navel show|url=http://telugustop.com/kona-behind-samantha-navel-show/|website=Telugustop.com|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.sareeoutlet.com/knowledgebase/Hot-Navel-Saree.html Hot Navel Saree] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140909195156/http://www.sareeoutlet.com/knowledgebase/Hot-Navel-Saree.html# |date=9 September 2014 }}. Sareeoutlet.com.</ref> In ancient Indian tradition, the navel of Lord [[Vishnu]] is considered to be the source of life and creativity. There's almost some sort of fascination with the navel in [[India]], because it is considered to be a symbol of birth and life. That means in ancient India, women would wear [[sari]] that bared their midriffs.<ref>[http://www.bharatsthali.com/blog Saree Draping Culture at BharatSthali]. BharatSthali.</ref>
Indian television actors have followed suit, wearing saris that expose more skin, including the navel, with viewers mimicking the styles.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kavita Awaasthi|title=TV girls take it up a notch|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Television/TV-girls-take-it-up-a-notch/Article1-907558.aspx|accessdate=11 August 2012|newspaper=Hindustan Times|date=3 August 2012}}</ref>
Some women wear navel jewels or [[navel piercing]]s to emphasize the navel and enhance its appeal.<ref name="southie"/><ref>[http://daily.bhaskar.com/article/ENT-navel-piercing-%E2%80%93-the-new-style-mantra-in-bollywood-2240524.html Navel piercing – the new style mantra in Bollywood!]. Daily.bhaskar.com (6 July 2011).</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7lvEN6lzSRMC&pg=PA43&dq=belly+button+sari&hl=en&ei=1GRuTumCJuvJ0AGh-p3fBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCDgU#v=onepage&q=belly%20button%20&f=false |title=Be Your Own Beautician |author=Parvesh Handa |publisher=Pustak Mahal |year=2007 |page=43 |isbn=9788122309737}}</ref> Another option is using ''[[Bindi (decoration)|bindis]]'' to decorate the navel.<ref>{{cite news|author=Sadhna Shanker|title=Bindi morphs into hip accessory|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/06/style/06iht-rbindi.html|accessdate=18 March 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=6 October 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Wara Karim|title=Bindi- An Unbeatable Fashion Accessory|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/lifestyle/2004/12/01/page01.htm|accessdate=18 March 2012|newspaper=Daily Star|date=7 December 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Debarati S Sen|title=Flaunt your midriff|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/beauty/Flaunt-your-midriff/articleshow/39545402.cms|accessdate=7 February 2015|work=Times of India|date=3 August 2014}}</ref> Tattoos near or below the navel were becoming popular in cities such as [[Pune]] in early 2012.<ref>{{cite news|author=Neha Kaura|title=Tattoo culture picking up in Pune|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-05-18/trends/31750557_1_tattoo-artist-tattoo-convention-tattoo-culture|accessdate=24 May 2012|newspaper=The Times of India|date=18 May 2012}}</ref> Actresses [[Mandira Bedi]] and [[Chhavi Mittal]] are known for their unique tattoos on their navels.<ref>{{cite web|title=Photo Feature - Stars and their Tattoos|url=http://photos.filmibeat.com/photo-feature/stars-their-tattoos/photos-c63-e42479-p310187.html|website=Filmibeat.com|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chhavi's love embedded on her navel|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/television/chhavi-s-love-embedded-on-her-navel/article1-374233.aspx|accessdate=8 August 2015|work=Hindustan Times|date=3 February 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Chhavi's love is embedded on her navel|url=http://www.filmibeat.com/television/news/2009/chhavi-navel-tattoo-200109.html|website=Filmibeat.com|accessdate=8 August 2015}}</ref>
Sometimes the low-rise style is modified, with the navel being covered by the pallu when wearing a low-rise non-transparent sari. In some corporations in India, saris are required to be worn in a manner that avoids navel exposure.<ref>{{cite book|author=Dr Saurabh Bhatia |title=Indian Corporate Etiquette |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bmnto6wQ-8cC |accessdate=11 June 2011 |publisher=Saurabh Bhatia |isbn=978-81-906964-0-1}}</ref> Anita Gupta, Senior Vice-President at [[J. Walter Thompson]] in [[Chennai]] commented that formal wear for woman should not expose the navel.<ref>{{cite news|author=Nina Varghese |author2=Raja Simhan T.E.|title=The workplace look|url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/todays-paper/article1759121.ece|accessdate=18 March 2012|newspaper=The Business Line|date=27 October 2006}}</ref>
===Indian cinema=== Indian actresses have expressed comfort with the practice of exposing their navels in film, preferring it to showing cleavage and calling it uncontroversial.<ref name="indiatoday.intoday.in"/><ref name="ben">{{cite news|title=She who dares to bare | url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1080804/jsp/entertainment/story_9640800.jsp | accessdate=13 March 2012 | date=4 August 2008 | newspaper=The Telegraph | location=Calcutta, India}}</ref>
====South Indian==== South Indian actresses such as [[Silk Smitha]], [[Simran (actress)|Simran]], [[Kiran Rathod]], [[Namitha]], [[Trisha Krishnan]], [[Anushka Shetty]], [[Shriya Saran]], [[Ileana D'Cruz]], [[Kajal Aggarwal]], [[Mumtaj]], [[Taapsee Pannu]], [[Shruti Hassan]], [[Tamannaah]], [[Samantha Ruth Prabhu]], [[Nayanthara]], [[Shwetha Menon]], etc., are known for their navel exposure.<ref name="indiatoday.intoday.in"/><ref>{{cite web |title=Sexy actresses' hot navel show in Telugu movies |author=Shekhar |date=8 November 2012 |publisher=Filmibeat |url=http://www.filmibeat.com/telugu/news/2012/tollywood-actresses-hot-navel-show-telugu-movies-101035.html#slidemore-slideshow-1}}</ref><ref name="sam"/> Actresses such as [[Ileana D'Cruz]], [[Tamannaah]], [[Shriya Saran]] etc., are known for exposing their slim [[midriff]]s in song sequences.<ref>{{cite news|author=Vanaja Banagiri|title=Southern sirens|url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/magazine/article1285656.ece|accessdate=24 August 2014|newspaper=The Times of India|date=7 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hottest Celebrity Midriffs|url=http://photogallery.navbharattimes.indiatimes.com/celebs/celeb-themes/hottest-celebrity-midriffs/articleshow/36292424.cms|website=indiatimes.com|accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref>
=====Tamil cinema===== During the 1990s, scenes focusing on the female protagonist's navel were common in [[Tamil cinema]].<ref>{{cite web |title=பம்பரம் விட்டு, தேள் விட்டு, ஆப்பாயில் போட்டு... பாவம்தான் நடிகைகள்! |language=Tamil |author=Sudha |date=9 October 2013 |publisher=Filmibeat |url=http://tamil.filmibeat.com/heroines/kollywood-still-concentrates-on-navel-185060.html}}</ref> Actress [[Sukanya (actress)|Sukanya]] became famous for a scene in the 1992 film ''[[Chinna Gounder]]'', where the main protagonist spins a top on the female protagonist's navel.<ref>{{cite web|title=Sukanya Profile |url=http://www.veethi.com/india-people/sukanya-profile-215-14.htm |website=veethi.com |accessdate=1 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=பம்பரம் விட்டு, தேள் விட்டு, ஆப்பாயில் போட்டு... பாவம்தான் நடிகைகள்! |language=Tamil |author=Sudha |date=9 October 2013 |publisher=Filmibeat |url=http://tamil.filmibeat.com/heroines/kollywood-still-concentrates-on-navel-185060.html#slide10569}}</ref> The 1993 film ''[[Gentleman (1993 film)|Gentleman]]'' featured a scene in the song sequence where female protagonist's navel is poked with a sword.<ref>{{cite web|title=Random Movies I Like - The Gentleman (1994)|url=http://gasbelly.blogspot.in/2007/07/random-movies-i-like-gentleman-1994.html|website=gasbelly.blogspot.in|accessdate=1 August 2015}}</ref> In 1996, actress [[Nagma]] became known for acting in a [[food play]] scene in the Tamil film ''[[Love Birds (1996 film)|Love Birds]]'', which involves the male protagonist breaking an egg and cooking it on her navel,<ref>[http://thatstamil.oneindia.in/movies/heroines/2005/07/lakshmirai.html வெத்தலை, வெத்தலை, வெத்தலையோ!]</ref><ref>[http://masalastuff.net/actress/nagma/sexy-compilation-from-movie-love-birds Nagma - Love Birds] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601054224/http://masalastuff.net/actress/nagma/sexy-compilation-from-movie-love-birds |date=1 June 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=பம்பரம் விட்டு, தேள் விட்டு, ஆப்பாயில் போட்டு... பாவம்தான் நடிகைகள்! |language=Tamil |author=Sudha |date=9 October 2013 |publisher=Filmibeat |url=http://tamil.filmibeat.com/heroines/kollywood-still-concentrates-on-navel-185060.html#slide10570}}</ref> which was similar to a scene from ''[[Hot Shots!]]'' (1991) involving [[Valeria Golino]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Phoebe Hoban |editor=Chris Smith |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E-kCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA22&lpg=PA22&dq=valeria+golino+navel&source=bl&ots=8I570oOfdD&sig=jQWwz37SGjpTDNyyZ8xbvR7ASTU&hl=en&ei=whRuTqfROMXW0QGC6qyFBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBTgK#v=onepage&q=valeria%20golino%20navel&f=false |title=Navel Maneuvers |work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] |date=12 August 1991}}</ref> In the early 2000s [[Simran Bagga]] was known for her navel exposure in films. Her pierced navel also drew many youths to the cinema for the 2002 film ''[[Pammal K. Sambandam]]''. In his review of ''[[Isai]]'' (2015), film critic [[Baradwaj Rangan]] stated that "[[Sulagna Panigrahi|Sulagna]] brings to mind the heroines of a certain era who were chosen not because they had beautiful eyes or a bewitching smile but because of the quiver-quotient of their navel when confronted by a close-up."<ref>{{cite news|author=Baradwaj Rangan|title=Isai: Lots of problems, but the preposterous plot pulls you through|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-reviews/isai-lots-of-problems-but-the-preposterous-plot-pulls-you-through/article6839653.ece|accessdate=1 February 2015|work=The Hindu|date=30 January 2015}}</ref> Film critic Sudhir Srinivasan wrote in a review for the 2016 film ''[[Aranmanai 2]]'', "The emphasis is not so much on making a horror story that is novel, than it is on fixating on the heroine’s navel."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sudhir Srinivasan|title=Aranmanai-2 : More navel than novel|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/cinema-reviews/aranmanai2-more-navel-than-novel/article8171574.ece|accessdate=7 February 2016|work=The Hindu|date=30 January 2016}}</ref>

Madhu Gopal|title=On 'top' of the world|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/on-top-of-the-world/article3192937.ece|accessdate=1 August 2015|work=The Hindu|date=20 May 2006}}</ref>

But actually he's not making any flower or fruit thrown at my navel or waist, that's why I took courage to ask him to hit my navel with them"<ref>{{cite web|title=Heroine To Director: Hit Me On My Navel|url=http://www.gulte.com/movienews/55944/Heroine-To-Director-Hit-Me-On-My-Navel|website=Gulte.com|accessdate=25 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=I Want That Navel Shot|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rcbzfg7g2wQ|accessdate=25 March 2017}}</ref>

====Contradictions==== The [[Censor Board of India]] for [[Indian cinema]] has created some limitations on "vulgar" visuals, such as restricting zoom shots of the navel, kissing the navel, and squeezing the navel and waist. It had been implemented during the 1990s.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WNS7LhIfiv8C&dq=erotic+navel&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Erotic justice: law and the new politics of postcolonialism |author=Ratna Kapur |publisher=Permanent Black |year=2005 |isbn=9788178241326}}</ref>{{page needed|date=December 2015}}<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Efv3V7Y9WzsC&pg=PA492&dq=vulgar+navel&hl=en&ei=q8zgTv-SHcfu0gGbzuC_Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=vulgar%20navel&f=false |title=Writing the women's movement: a reader |author=Shohini Ghosh |chapter=The Troubled Existence of Sex and Sexuality: Feminists Engage with Censorship |editor=Mala Khullar |publisher=Zubaan |year=2005 |isbn=9788186706992 |pages=491–492}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Usha Rai|title=New censorship proposals on 1994}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Censor Guidelines|url=http://www.chitraloka.com/exclusive/823-censor-guidelines.html|website=Chitraloka.com|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref> Many films have faced August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=List of Censor Cuts in Aagadu|url=http://www.gulte.com/movienews/30742/List-of-Censor-Cuts-in-Aagadu|website=Gulte.com|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Why 'A' Certificate for 'Power'?|url=http://www.iqlikmovies.com/news/article/2014/09/04/reason-behind-ravi-teja-power-getting-a-certificat/5352|website=iqlikmovies.com|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref>
Many actors have expressed mixed views on the display of and emphasize of the navel. Some feel displaying the midriff or navel cannot be considered exposing when compared to Hollywood films.<ref>{{cite journal |publisher=Sahara India Mass Communication |journal=Rashtriya Sahara |date=1995 |volume=3 |issue=7-12 |page=170 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SxxuAAAAMAAJ&q=Rashtriya+Sahara+belly+button&dq=Rashtriya+Sahara+belly+button&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBsQ6AEwAGoVChMI5r6b8N_-yAIVRgeOCh3_YgET |title= <!--unavailable at web link -->|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref> Actress [[Shilpa Shetty]] argued, "If navel-showing is obscenity, then our traditional Indian outfit{{mdash}}the traditional sari{{mdash}}should be banned in the first place."<ref>{{cite news | work=The Times of India | title=If navel is obscene, let's ban saris | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/bangalore-times/if-navel-is-obscene-lets-ban-saris/articleshow/1504414.cms | accessdate=4 January 2007 | first1=Afsana | last1=Ahmed | first2=Smrity | last2=Sharma | date=25 April 2006}}</ref> Actress, BJP member and CBFC member [[Jeevitha]] while speaking on item numbers stated, "Dance numbers are okay, but girls don't need to dress vulgarly. They can wear skirts but not too much below the navel."<ref>{{cite news|author=Dipti Nagpaul|title=Know Your Censors|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/know-your-censors/|accessdate=3 August 2015|work=The Indian Express|date=1 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Andre Borges|title=22 Things We Know About The Indian Censor Board|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/andreborges/cbfc-facts#.toaxGpkQJ|website=Buzzfeed.com|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref> Telugu film director [[Pasupuleti Krishna Vamsi|Krishna Vamsi]] commented, "All film-makers have problems with the censors. They sometimes object to showing the navel of a woman when, in other films, it is allowed. We cannot even question them. The censors should give us general rules in writing as to what is allowed and what is not, instead of taking decisions according to their whims and fancies."<ref>{{cite web|author1=Sunil Kumar|title='I want to be a free bird'|url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/nov/17kri.htm|website=rediff.com|accessdate=15 August 2014}}</ref> Actor [[R. Madhavan]] commented, "I have often been embarrassed to see certain films I have done. ... when I see myself kissing a dancing heroine's navel in some films, I feel ashamed."<ref>{{cite news|author=Rana Siddiqui Zaman|title=Wisdom of an idiot | url=http://www.hindu.com/fr/2009/12/25/stories/2009122550080100.htm | accessdate=12 April 2012 | newspaper=The Hindu | date=25 December 2009 | location=Chennai, India}}</ref> Actress [[Taapsee Pannu]] commented, "I believe the navel is overrated. I think sensuality can be expressed in other ways."<ref name="tnav" /> Bengali actress [[Swastika Mukherjee]] said, "I am not very comfortable though I have tried wearing a ''lehenga choli'' with a stick-on in my navel."<ref name="ben" /> Many actresses have opted to hide their navels by wearing [[trikini]]s for beach or pool scenes.<ref>{{cite web|title=Heroines hiding their navel in bikini|url=http://www.idleindia.com/2013/03/heroines-hiding-their-navel-in-bikini.html#axzz3AQsDleTt|website=idleindia.com|accessdate=24 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826160750/http://www.idleindia.com/2013/03/heroines-hiding-their-navel-in-bikini.html#axzz3AQsDleTt#axzz3AQsDleTt|archive-date=26 August 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Ram Kumar|url=http://www.southdreamz.com/51837/why-taapsee-hides-navel/|title=Why Taapsee Hides [Her] Navel|website=southdreamz|accessdate=24 August 2014|date=6 March 2013}}</ref>
==Japanese culture== [[File:Figurine Dogu Jomon Musée Guimet 70608 4.jpg|thumb|upright|left|[[Dogū]] figurine of the late [[Jōmon period]] with the navel indicated with a deep indentation.]]
===Early times=== Japan has long had a special regard for the navel. During the early [[Jōmon period]] in northern Japan, three small balls indicating the breasts and navel were pasted onto flat clay objects to represent the female body. The navel was exaggerated in size, informed by the belief that the navel symbolizes the center of where life begins. On many middle Jomon figurines, the significance of the navel was emphasized with an indentation or hole. Sometimes, the importance of the navel was further enhanced by connecting with a line from the navel towards the chest.<ref>{{cite book |author=[[Nelly Naumann]] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Yrla4QyhFasC&pg=PA114&dq=navel+japan&hl=en&ei=l-7kTsmJEaX50gHu_YiGBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAjgK#v=snippet&q=navel%20chest&f=false |title=Japanese prehistory: the material and spiritual culture of the Jōmon period |publisher=Otto Harrassowitz Verlag |year=2000 |isbn=9783447043298 |page=199}}</ref> Early Japanese poems feature many references to the female navel. In some, the word ''navel'' actually refers to an indentation or hole instead of the belly button.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hI6Ity0NPh4C&pg=PA192&dq=navel+japan&hl=en&ei=ce7kTq3VHOne0QGV-cT0BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=navel%20japan&f=false |title=The Woman Without a Hole – & Other Risky Themes from Old Japanese Poems |author=Robin D. Gill |publisher=Paraverse Press |year=2007 |chapter=Balls |isbn=9780974261881 |page=192}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EDZoEZ4CS3AC&pg=PA192&dq=navel+japan&hl=en&ei=ce7kTq3VHOne0QGV-cT0BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=navel%20japan&f=false |title=Octopussy, Dry Kidney & Blue Spots, Or, Senryû: Dirty Themes from 18-19c Japanese Poems |author=Robin D. Gill |chapter=Balls |publisher=Paraverse Press |year=2007 |isbn=9780974261850 |page=192}}</ref><!-- these two books seem to be the same, at least on this page, even though the book titles and ISBNs are different --> The shape of the umbilicus of a newborn baby would be discussed at length. If a baby's navel points downward, the parents would brace themselves for a weakling child who will bring them woe. The thunder god [[Raijin]], with his terrifying drums, great horns, and long tusks, was said to have an insatiable appetite for young navels, and mothers had to nag their youngsters constantly to keep themselves well covered up.<ref>[http://time-demo.newscred.com/article/6fac8c501d2457ee0ecc55a81e357b88.html/edit JAPAN: Navel Exercise] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120424104647/http://time-demo.newscred.com/article/6fac8c501d2457ee0ecc55a81e357b88.html/edit# |date=24 April 2012 }} – ''Time''</ref> Due to the mythology, navel exposure was not encouraged in the earlier times. The traditional clothing of Japanese women has a wide cloth belt around the [[midriff]] to protect the belly and keep it warm. The Japanese believe the belly is the source of person's warmth and that the perfect navel is an innie.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jB5vyH-XmQkC&pg=PA204&dq=navel+jeans+japan&hl=en&ei=hvDkTo7PDqXn0QH1_IyKBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CEIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=navel%20&f=false |title=The Pocket Guide to Girl Stuff |author=Bart King |publisher=Gibbs Smith |year=2008 |isbn=9781423607700 |page=204}}</ref>
===Modern times=== [[File:Yosakoi Performers at Kochi Yosakoi 2006 17.jpg|thumb|Japanese women performing a traditional Japanese dance [[Yosakoi]] in navel-exposing attire in the Yosakoi Matsuri 2006 at [[Kōchi, Kōchi|Kōchi]]]] Although navel exposure has become a recent trend in fashion in Japan, annual ''Heso Matsuri'' ("belly button festivals")<ref>{{cite book|author=Bruce Roscoe|title=Windows on Japan: a walk through place and perception|year=2007|publisher=Algora Publishing|isbn= 9780875864914|page=308|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kzt4R7tGuloC&pg=PA168&dq=belly+button+attraction&hl=en&sa=X&ei=loU0T_DsD8qbtwf84JilCA&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBjgK#v=onepage&q=belly%20button%20&f=false}}</ref> have been held in Japan since the late 1960s. The tradition of the [[Hokkaido]] ''Heso Odori'' ("belly button dance") began in 1968.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.freshpowder.com/?p=572 |title=43rd Hokkaido Belly Button Festival (Hokkai Heso Matsuri) Schedule |date=26 July 2011 |publisher=Japan Fresh Powder |accessdate=4 March 2012}}</ref> Dancers make their ''heso'' ("belly button") into a face, using paint, special costumes, and props. Many variations of the dance have been developed, leading to competitions among dancers, who compete for prizes in various categories.<ref>[http://www.furano-kankou.com/english/hyperlinks/F-furano_heso.htm Furano Heso/Belly Button Festival]. Furano-kankou.com {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116053613/http://www.furano-kankou.com/english/hyperlinks/F-furano_heso.htm |date=16 January 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=James |url=http://www.japanprobe.com/2009/07/30/hokkaido-belly-button-festival/ |title=Hokkaido Belly Button Festival |publisher=Japan Probe |date=30 July 2009 |access-date=2 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416221944/http://www.japanprobe.com/2009/07/30/hokkaido-belly-button-festival/# |archive-date=16 April 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Sandy |date=30 July 2008 |url=http://traveloncloud9.wordpress.com/2008/07/30/belly-button-festival/ |title=The 40th Belly Button Festival |publisher=Travel on Cloud 9}}</ref><ref>Sorensen, Callie. (5 July 2008) [http://whereiscallie.blogspot.com/2008/07/furan.html Furano Belly Button Festival]. Whereiscallie.blogspot.com.</ref>
A similar type festival is held at [[Shibukawa]], north of Tokyo. The idea was formed based on the location of Shibukawa, which is also referred to as the "Belly Button of Japan". The festival is based on a traditional Japanese form of entertainment where revelers paint a face on their torsos and stomachs to appear as a head. A ''[[kimono]]'' is wrapped around the waist, and the person's real head is hidden by a large cloth hat. The belly button is traditionally painted into a mouth. In recent years, modern motifs and Japanese anime designs have appeared in the festival.<ref>Muramoto, Hiroyuki. (28 July 2008) [https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/07/28/us-japan-bellybutton-idUSSP29709920080728 Celebrating the navel in Japan's "belly button"]. Reuters.</ref><ref>[http://www.japanprobe.com/2008/07/30/shibukawa-belly-button-festival/ Shibukawa belly button festival] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140417070459/http://www.japanprobe.com/2008/07/30/shibukawa-belly-button-festival/# |date=17 April 2014 }}. Japan Probe (30 July 2008).</ref>
==Sri Lankan culture== [[File:Sigiriya ladies 02.jpg|thumb|left|7th-century [[Sigiriya]] frescoes depicting women in navel-exposed attire]]
===Ancient times=== [[File:Sri Lankan dance - Sri Lankan Friendship Association of BC - 02.jpg|thumb|Sinhalese women performing a traditional Sri Lankan dance in navel-exposing attire]] [[Sigiriya]] frescoes depict royal ladies wearing cloth draped as a ''[[dhoti]]'', tied in a knot at the front and pulled down to expose the navel. They wear pleated robes from the waist upwards, as well a necklace, armlets, wristlets, ear and hair ornaments, and display their breasts. The ladies in waiting wear waist clothes, a few ornaments and a firm ''thanapatiya'' ("breast bandage").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://livingheritage.org/toplessness.htm |title=The Garb of Innocence: A Time of Toplessness |publisher=Living Heritage Trust}} republished from {{cite news |author=Romesh Fernando |work=The Island |title=The Garb of Innocence: A Time of Toplessness |date=15 November 1992}}</ref>
In the Sinhalese poetic work Kaviyasekara, a father advises his married daughter as to proper clothing, "Dress your garment above your navel, without exposing the fair bosom, and expose not your teeth in laughing."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-rK7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA202&dq=ceylon+belly+button&hl=en&ei=oy-QTvfLHMeCtgeJi-mfDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=kaviyasekara&f=false |title=A descriptive catalogue of Sanskrit, Pali, & Sinhalese literary works of Ceylon |author=James De Alwis |publisher=W. Skeen, government printer |location=Ceylon |year=1870 |pages=201–202}}</ref>
In his work ''Daily Code for the Laity'' (1898), the Buddhist leader [[Anagarika Dharmapala]] wrote that a sari blouse must be long, fully covering a woman's breasts, midriff, navel, and back.<ref>{{cite book|author=Kumari Jayawardena |author2=Malathi De Alwis|title=Embodied Violence: Communalising Women's Sexuality in South Asia|year=1996|publisher=Zed Books|isbn= 9781856494489|page=299|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=i2AObmt7Z8wC&pg=PA104&dq=navel+sari&hl=en&sa=X&ei=gCHAT5BHw-qsB5OTkckJ&ved=0CGAQ6AEwBTgo#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false}}</ref>
===Recent times=== In the 1980s and 1990s, a visible navel was very rare. By the late 1990s, the Bollywood connection and the media and technological changes that occurred in India had influenced Sri Lanka's fashion outlook, with the navel becoming a focus in the modern Sri Lankan wardrobe.<ref name="nat">{{cite news|author=Vihanga Perera|title=Navel warfare|url=http://www.nation.lk/edition/fine/item/6189-navel-warfare.html|accessdate=24 May 2012|newspaper=The Nation|date=20 May 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116053630/http://www.nation.lk/edition/fine/item/6189-navel-warfare.html|archivedate=16 January 2013|dead-url=yes}}</ref> Sri Lankan films commonly depict the women of the country's earliest history as scantily clad with exposed navels, and the country has become more open to the topic in general.<ref name="nat" /> In Nov 2015, Western Province Chief Minister [[Isura Devapriya]] stated that a school dress code for students and teachers would be issued requiring that the navel be covered. However, the Ceylon Teachers Union President Joseph Stalin condemned it and commented, "We condemn this statement. It is an anachronistic proposal. We see nothing wrong with teachers wearing sarees below the belly button. It may be that there is something wrong with Mr. Devapriya’s eye sight. We like to ask the Chief Minister whether the belly button is the main concern facing the education sector in the Western Province".<ref>{{cite news|last1=Piyumi Fonseka|title=Is navel the education sector’s main concern: CTU|url=http://www.dailymirror.lk/94737/is-navel-the-education-sector-s-main-concern-ctu-asks|accessdate=24 March 2017|work=Daily Mirror|date=10 November 2015}}</ref>
==Indonesian culture== [[File:Agnes at AMI 2004.jpg|thumb|left|[[Agnez Mo]] in navel exposing attire at the 2004 [[Anugerah Musik Indonesia|AMI Awards]]]] In 2004, the [[President of Indonesia]] [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]] spoke out against exposed navels, saying, "Indonesian women, who are known for their courtesy, should refrain from exposing their midriffs or belly buttons, which now seems to be taken for granted. There are many ways to express beauty, as part of aesthetics, and to express freedom but not by showing things that lead to pornography." He further added that while the state could not dictate dress codes, citizens were expected to respect the country's moral values and courtesy. A week later, a cabinet minister quoted Yudhoyono as saying that he felt "disturbed and uneasy" to see television shows in which women exposed their navels.<ref>[http://www.thejakartafpost.com/news/2004/12/22/contemplating-susilo039s-navel-fixation.html "Contemplating Susilo's navel fixation"]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. ''The Jakarta Post''. (22 December 2004).</ref><ref>[http://www.glapn.org/sodomylaws/world/indonesia/idnews004.htm "Indonesian President Bellyaches about Exposed Belly Buttons"] – AFP. Glapn.org.</ref>
In 2006, Agus Suwage, an Indonesian artist, installed his Pinkswing Park exhibit at [[Jakarta]]'s international biennale.The exhibit was surrounded by massive panels with multiple pictures of a near-naked man and woman frolicking in a park. Within days of the exhibition's launch, Islamic fundamentalists had descended on the biennale, forcing its closure and demanding prosecutions. At first police claimed his work blasphemed the story of [[Adam and Eve]]; a few weeks later they told Suwage he faced five years in jail for producing pornography. The Indonesian parliament decided to introduce a sweeping anti-pornography law. The law imposes a rigid social template; couples who kiss in public will face up to five years' jail, as would anyone flaunting a "sensual body part"—including their navel—and tight clothing will be outlawed.<ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2006/02/24/1140670261932.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap3 Navel gazing ruled out as Indonesians button up]. ''The Sydney Morning Herald''. (24 February 2006).</ref><ref name="m">[http://www.martinfrost.ws/htmlfiles/miniskirt1.html Miniskirts and hipsters threatened in Indonesia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726041429/http://martinfrost.ws/htmlfiles/miniskirt1.html# |date=26 July 2014 }}. Martinfrost.ws (28 March 2006).</ref><ref>[http://javaliese.livejournal.com/34254.html Ahh, the Indonesian porn bill]. Javaliese.livejournal.com (3 March 2006).</ref> Due to this new anti-pornography law, topless bathing and surfing on the beaches of [[Bali]], a common practice among tourists, would also be prohibited. The law would also affect older tribal women, who often still walk topless.<ref name="m" /><ref>{{cite news |author=Amy Chavez |url=http://www.thebalitimes.com/2008/09/26/no-more-surfing-naked/ |title=No More Surfing Naked! |publisher=The Bali Times |date=26 September 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Amy Chavez |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/fl20060311cz.html |title=No more nude surfing in Bali |publisher=The Japan Times |date=11 March 2006}}</ref> The introduction of a bill was attacked by women's rights campaigners in the country, who fear it is the first step towards the implementation of Islamic [[Sharia]] law.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/5012330.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Indonesian fears over porn law | date=25 May 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Pam Allen |journal=Intersections: Gender and Sexuality in Asia and the Pacific |issue=19 |date=February 2009 |url=http://intersections.anu.edu.au/issue19/allen.htm |title=Women, Gendered Activism and Indonesia's Anti-Pornography Bill}}</ref>
Despite these laws, [[Pop music|pop]] singers such as [[Inul Daratista]], known for her hip swaying moves,<ref name="m" /><ref>{{cite news |author=Bret Stephens |date=3 April 2007 |url=http://www.libforall.org/media/news-stories/WSJ_Hips-Don-t-Lie.pdf |title=Hips don't lie |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |access-date=2 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116053613/http://www.libforall.org/media/news-stories/WSJ_Hips-Don-t-Lie.pdf# |archive-date=16 January 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>[http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2005/04/25/inul-go-ahead-kl-concert.html Inul to go ahead with KL concert] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620064322/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2005/04/25/inul-go-ahead-kl-concert.html# |date=20 June 2013 }}. ''The Jakarta Post''. (25 April 2005).</ref> and [[Agnez Mo]] continue exposing their navels, but undergo some restrictions in [[advertisement]]s.<ref>[http://www.scandasia.com/viewNews.php?coun_code=plus&news_id=7109 Shariah in Aceh: Eroding Secular Freedoms] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116053613/http://www.scandasia.com/viewNews.php?coun_code=plus&news_id=7109# |date=16 January 2013 }}. Scandasia.com (21 August 2010).</ref>
==Korean culture== Traditionally, Korean women are expected to dress modestly. The traditional wear such as [[Hanbok]] cover the entire body.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tina Kim Chu|title=Korean Customs and Etiquette Handbook|url=http://www.2id.korea.army.mil/korea/pdf/Korean_Customs_and_Etiquette_Handbook.pdf|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Yuri at KBS Hope Concert 2013 01.jpg|thumb|right|150px|South Korean singer [[Kwon Yu-ri|Yuri]] performing at KBS Hope Concert in January 2013]]
===1990s=== During the 1990s, the fashion trend among young South Korean women for wearing cropped [[T-shirt]]s that leave the midriff exposed had started, due to the hot climatic conditions. The trend spread to create changes in female fashion such that when a policeman in [[Gwangju]] arrested two young women for flaunting their belly buttons in the street, the judge threw the case out, ruling that the flashing of a female navel was not indecent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Navel-flashing Ruled Decent|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-10-09/features/9410090491_1_south-korea-sexual-harassment-suit-navel|accessdate=22 March 2015|agency=The Economist Newspaper Limited|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=9 October 1994}}</ref> It further became popular due to Korean pop culture, where [[K-pop]] stars started wearing body piercings<ref>{{cite web|author=Cara Ribeiro|title=Top 10 Idols with Piercings|url=http://blog.ningin.com/2011/10/07/top-10-idols-with-multiple-piercings/|website=Ningin|accessdate=22 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150315032310/http://blog.ningin.com/2011/10/07/top-10-idols-with-multiple-piercings/#|archive-date=15 March 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and midriff-exposing shirts.<ref>{{cite news|author=Rachel|title=Interview: SPICA talks about their comeback and lip-sync|url=http://www.hellokpop.com/news/interview-spica-talks-about-their-comeback-and-lip-sync/|accessdate=22 March 2015|work=HelloKpop|date=10 October 2012}}</ref> In July 1997, the South Korean broadcaster [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS]] announced tough new rules for pop stars appearing on TV. One among the many limitations was "no exposing of navels".<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard King |author2=Timothy J. Craig|title=Global Goes Local: Popular Culture in Asia|year=2003|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|isbn= 9789622095915|pages=320|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s4LR2X1rIIEC&dq=korean+pop+navel&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref>
===2000s=== During the 2000s, it became common among young women to expose their belly buttons by rolling up their shirts similar to a crop-top. During sport events such as football, the female audience apply body paints or temporary tattoos around their belly buttons.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Rachael Miyung Joo |title=Consuming Visions: The Crowds of the Korean World Cup |journal=The Journal of Korean Studies |volume=11 |number=1 |date=Fall 2006 |isbn=1442234849|page=53 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oGU-AwAAQBAJ&dq=korea+belly+button+dance&q=belly+button#v=snippet&q=belly%20button&f=false |accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref> In 2010, Korean girl group [[Rainbow (South Korean group)|Rainbow]]'s dance routine that involved lifting up their shirts to expose their navels became popular. The band stated in an interview, "We have to keep our abs in shape for the belly button dance."<ref>{{cite web|title=Korean idol group Rainbow to debut in Japan this fall!|url=http://www.tokyohive.com/article/2011/06/korean-idol-group-rainbow-to-debut-in-japan-this-fall|website=Tokyohive.com|accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref> But the routine was subsequently has been banned.<ref>{{cite news|title=Korean Girl Bands Bare More Skin in Japan|url=http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/04/13/2013041300346.html|accessdate=3 August 2015|work=Chosun|date=13 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=No Belly Dance, Rainbow|url=http://www.asianrice.tv/news/No-Belly-Dance-Rainbow/687|website=asianrice.tv |accessdate=3 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=8 September 2010 |author=Syee22 |url=http://www.dkpopnews.net/2010/09/news-rainbow-belly-button-dance-banned.html |title=Rainbow 'Belly button dance', banned from broadcast |publisher=Daily kpop news}}</ref> The [[Seoul Broadcasting System|SBS]] TV show ''[[Inkigayo]]'' told girl groups to restrain showing their skin too much and about their outfits.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rainbow's Fans Disappointed Because They Were "Too Sexy"|url=http://www.kpopstarz.com/articles/4292/20120209/rainbow-japan-too-sexy.htm|publisher=KpopStarz|accessdate=16 October 2013}}</ref><ref>[http://news.nate.com/view/20100908n09893 레인보우 '배꼽춤', 방송금지 "선정적, 수정 불가피"]. News.nate.com.</ref> In 2013, [[Im Yoona|Yoona]], a member of Korean girl band [[Girls' Generation]], caused a minor controversy by revealing an exposed midriff featuring a protruding cantaloupe-like outie navel, which started a spirited discussion and polarized opinions on the Chinese-language internet.<ref>{{cite news|title=Korean starlet's belly button causes navel-gazing online|url=http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20130213000015&cid=1103|accessdate=16 October 2013|newspaper=WantChinaTimes|date=13 February 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016063712/http://www.wantchinatimes.com/news-subclass-cnt.aspx?id=20130213000015&cid=1103#|archive-date=16 October 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=SNSD's Yoona shows off a new look and cute bellybutton |url=https://en.korea.com/blog/enter/k-pop/snsds-yoona-shows-off-a-new-look-and-cute-bellybutton/ |publisher=Korea.com |accessdate=16 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130106041015/http://en.korea.com/blog/enter/k-pop/snsds-yoona-shows-off-a-new-look-and-cute-bellybutton/ |archivedate=6 January 2013 }}</ref>
Although, the formal wear is expected to cover the stomach and belly button.<ref>{{cite book|author=Un-yŏng Kim|title=A Cross-cultural Reference of Business Practices in a New Korea|date=1996|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=1567200192|pages=157|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cj583eSAXP0C&dq=korea+bellybutton&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=22 March 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Malay fashions.JPG|right|upright|thumb|Malay [[model (person)|models]] in attire that covers the navel at a fashion show in [[Kuala Lumpur]] in April 2011]]
==Malaysian culture== In 2005, Vivienne, a virtual girlfriend created by software maker Artificial Life Inc. of [[Hong Kong]], was reprogrammed not to bare her navel or display body piercings in conservative Muslim countries including Malaysia to avoid problems.<ref>{{cite news |author=Keith Bradsher |date=24 February 2005 |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/24/technology/24girlfriend.html |title=Sad, Lonely? For a Good Time, Call Vivienne*}}</ref> In 2006, [[Nik Abdul Aziz Nik Mat]] gave his blessings to an Islamic form of dance clubs to serve as entertainment outlets at [[Kota Bharu]]. He commented that there must be proper attire for women, including clothes that do not reveal the navel, saying Muslim women must be covered from head to toe except for their face and hands, while Muslim men must be decently dressed when in public.<ref>[http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/12/17/nation/16348816&sec=nation PAS-style dance clubs]. ''The Star''. {{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> Under Malaysian government rules for stage performances, a female artist must be covered from her shoulders to her knees. This law prevented pop icon [[Beyoncé Knowles]] from performing in navel-exposing attire in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |author=Sean Yoong |agency=Associated Press |date=23 August 2007 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/08/22/AR2007082202743.html |title=Pop Stars Learn: When in Malaysia ... |newspaper=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>[http://www.chron.com/entertainment/article/Malaysian-officials-tell-Beyonce-to-cover-up-1832486.php Malaysian officials tell Beyoncé to cover up]. ''Houston Chronicle''. (23 August 2007).</ref> Beyoncé canceled the show amid opposition from local groups, calling the cancellation a result of a "scheduling conflict".<ref>[http://www.singersroom.com/news/4471/Beyonce-To-Put-Clothes-On-It-For-Malaysia- Beyonce To Put 'Clothes On It' For Malaysia ?]{{dead link|date=December 2015}}</ref>
==Views in alternative medicine from antiquity== Saint [[Thomas Aquinas]] considered the navel as the "bodily metaphor for spiritual things".<ref>{{cite news|author=Vithal C Nadkarni|title=The navel's key significance|url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2006-05-24/news/27455537_1_navel-belly-button-lotus|accessdate=28 August 2012|newspaper=The Times of India|date=24 May 2006}}</ref>
===Alternative medicine=== [[File:Manipura2.svg|thumb|upright|Manipura chakra that represents the navel]]
===Indian medicine=== In Indian traditional medicine, the ''[[Cyperus rotundus]]'' tuber is made into a paste and applied around the navel to relieve pain caused by [[roundworm]]s. [[Pomegranate]] plant juice and paste is used to treat [[snake bite]]s; the juice is dropped into the nostrils, ears, and navel.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y1GEsMSCOBQC&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Medicinal plants of the world: Chemical Constituents, Traditional and Modern Medicinal Uses |author=Ivan A. Ross |publisher=Humana Press |year=2003 |isbn=9781588292810}}</ref>{{page needed|date=December 2015}} Applying a little bit of [[ghee]] or [[mustard oil]] on cotton and keeping it on the navel overnight is considered a remedy for [[Chapped lips|dry lips]].<ref>[http://www.bangaloremirror.com/article/74/20110411201104112044377935224586/Why-Rahul-Dravid-puts-ghee-on-his-navel.html Why Rahul Dravid puts ghee on his navel]. Bangaloremirror.com. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110827001125/http://www.bangaloremirror.com/article/74/20110411201104112044377935224586/Why-Rahul-Dravid-puts-ghee-on-his-navel.html |date=27 August 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=8 Tips to Get Pink Lips Naturally|url=http://www.bollywoodshaadis.com/article/lifestyle--health/health--fitness/8-tips-to-get-pink-lips-naturally/page/3|publisher=BollywoodShaadis.com|accessdate=20 May 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130608052305/http://www.bollywoodshaadis.com/article/lifestyle--health/health--fitness/8-tips-to-get-pink-lips-naturally/page/3#|archive-date=8 June 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Castor oil]] is applied to the navel of infants as a remedy for [[Abdominal pain|stomach aches]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Sheela Rani Chunkath|title=A healthy ritual|url=http://www.hindu.com/mag/2003/01/12/stories/2003011200150700.htm|accessdate=11 April 2012|newspaper=The Hindu|date=12 January 2003|location=Chennai, India}}</ref> The [[Gonds]], a tribe from central India, apply ''[[Gloriosa superba]]'' [[rhizome]] extract over the navel and vagina to cause [[labour pain]] and perform normal delivery.<ref>{{cite book|author=R. D. Tribhuwan|title=Body Image, Human Reproduction and Birth Control|year=2009|publisher=Discovery Publishing House|isbn= 9788183563888|page=280|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VYYoDoJTwIkC&pg=PA129&dq=choli+navel&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UkGIT5OROMnmrAfRrNCQCw&ved=0CF8Q6AEwCDgo#v=onepage&q=%20navel&f=false}}</ref>
According to [[Ayurveda]], the navel is an important site in the human body. Nearly 72,000 subtle nerves, or [[Nadi (yoga)|''nadis'']] converge in this area.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q8ryo-SyO3UC&pg=PA77&dq=navel+massage&hl=en&ei=yKlkTsnVHsTcgQer3oC7Cg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=navel%20massage&f=false |title=Ayurvedic massage: traditional Indian techniques for balancing body and mind |author=Harish Johari |publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co |year=1996 |isbn=9780892814893 |page=77}}</ref> By the principles of Ayurveda and [[yoga]], the human body is made up of six ''[[chakra]]s'', with the ''[[Manipura]] chakra'' located at the spine directly behind either the navel or the [[solar plexus]], depending on the system, while its ''[[kshetram]]'', or superficial activation point, is located directly on the navel and represents the element [[fire (element)|fire]].<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uOeSLZsp7lwC&pg=PA157&dq=dancer+navel+india&hl=en&ei=wetpTou7OOfz0gG6jL3iBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEwQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false |title=The Hidden Mysteries of Kundalini |author=R. Venugopalam |publisher=B. Jain Publishers |year=2004 |isbn=9788180560033}}</ref>{{page needed|date=December 2015}}<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=99thvrs56AMC&dq=navel+ayurveda&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Chakras: Energy Centers of Transformation |author=Harish Johari |publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co |year=2000 |isbn=9781594779091|page=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=atPiE5-3b94C&dq=navel+ayurveda&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=The Encyclopedia of Ayurvedic Massage |author=John Douillard |publisher=North Atlantic Books, |year=2004 |isbn=9781556434938 |page=33}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hIFqoZY7Uj0C&q=navel+fire#v=snippet&q=navel%20fire&f=false |title=Ayurvedic Message for Health and Healing |author=S. V. Govindan |publisher=Abhinav Publications |year=2000 |isbn=9788170173939 |page=106}}</ref> [[Vayu]] or vital wind as specified in Ayurveda, is divided into five sub categories. Of these, Samāna Vayu, situated in the navel region, is believed to aid in [[digestion]] and give physical strength to the body.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gp3vyt9pTaAC&dq=navel+ayurveda&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Ayurvedic healing cuisine: 200 vegetarian recipes for health, balance, and longevity |author=Harish Johari |publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co |year=2000 |isbn=9780892819386|page=7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CBEqgAIh7XcC&dq=navel+ayurveda&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=Secrets of Ayurvedic Massage |author=Atreya <!-- Craig Smith [citation needed] --> |publisher=Lotus Press |year=2000 |isbn=9780914955498 |page=22}}</ref>
According to Ayurvedic principles, [[navel displacement]] is a condition in which the navel center shifts. This might create digestive disorders. Proper practice of yoga is considered to be a remedy to realigning the navel.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1OkrH1ZYPOwC&pg=PT282&dq=navel+displacement&hl=en&ei=LhLfTuzUFoHm0QHHv9C9Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=navel%20&f=false |title=The Ayurveda Encyclopedia: Natural Secrets to Healing, Prevention, & Longevity |author=Swami Sadashiva Tirtha |publisher=Sat Yuga Press |year=2007 |isbn=9780965804257 |page=265}}</ref>
===Sri Lankan medicine=== In Sri Lanka traditional medicine, a composition of herbs, powdered pepper, and water is applied as a paste to the navel as a remedy for stomach aches.<ref>{{cite book |author=Philip Baldaeus |chapter=Jaffna and Kandy through the Eyes of a Dutch Reformed ''Predikant'' |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Kj_aWm4DeFEC&q=navel#v=snippet&q=navel&f=false |title=The Sri Lanka Reader: History, Culture, Politics |editor1=John Clifford Holt <!-- |editor2=Robin Kirk |editor3=Orin Starn [citation needed] --> |publisher=Duke University Press |year=2011 |isbn=9780822349822 |page=206}}</ref> During difficulties in delivery, a [[betel leaf]] is placed on the woman's navel, which is believed to be under a spell.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=INQUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA247&dq=ceylon+belly+button&hl=en&ei=dy-QTpj8M4_AtgeG0NGgDA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false |title=Exorcism and the Art of Healing in Ceylon |author=Paul Wirz |publisher=Brill Archive |year=1954 |page=247}}</ref>
===Russian medicine=== Laying [[Artemisia (plant)|wormwood]] on the female navel or spreading a paste of [[reindeer lichen]] on the navel were considered by Russian women to make the delivery of a child fast and painless.<ref>{{cite book |author=Eve Levin |chapter=Childbirth in Pre-Petrine Russia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4qwXqg82n1gC&pg=PA56&lpg=PA55&dq=russia+navel#v=onepage&q=navel&f=false |title=Russia's Women: Accommodation, Resistance, Transformation |editor=Barbara Evans Clements |editor2=Barbara Alpern Engel |editor3=Christine Worobec |publisher=University of California Press |year=1991 |isbn=9780520070240 |page=55}}</ref>
===Chinese medicine=== In the Chinese art of [[acupuncture]], the navel is sometimes referred to as 神阙 (''shénquè'', roughly translating to '''divine imperfection''' or '''mark of the ancestors'''). Often, the navel is used as a [[moxibustion]] point. However, the navel itself is not used in acupuncture due to the likelihood of infection.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://baike.baidu.com/view/389284.htm |title=shén què |publisher=Baidu Baike |language=ja}}</ref>
{{Clear}}
==See also== * [[Crop top]] * [[Navel fetishism]] * [[Alvinolagnia]] * [[Toplessness]] * [[Waistline (clothing)]]

{{italic title}} '''''Dance of the Tiger''''' (Swedish: ''Den Svarta Tigern'') is a novel by Swedish [[palaeontology|palaeontologist]] [[Björn Kurtén]], published in 1978 and English translation in 1980. It is a [[Prehistoric fiction|prehistoric novel]] dealing with the interaction between [[Neanderthals]] and [[Cro-Magnons]]. A sequel, ''[[Singletusk]]'', published in 1982, continues the story of the family.
==Plot== Set 35,000 years ago in Scandinavia, during a thaw in the great [[Ice Age]], the novel follows a Cro-Magnon named Tiger as he tries to defeat Shelk, a tyrant and a hybrid (Neanderthal/Cro-Magnon), the man who killed his father. With his family and much of his tribe dead, Tiger meets, interacts, and allies himself with groups of Neanderthals. He eventually marries a Neanderthal woman.
==Depictions== Neanderthals are depicted as white-skinned, while Cro-Magnons are dark. Kurtén's skin color identification for both populations appears to agree with recent DNA studies, including those proposing the African origin of modern humans.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1130343100 |date=May 2003 |author1=Caramelli, D |author2=Lalueza-Fox, C |author3=Vernesi, C |author4=Lari, M |author5=Casoli, A |author6=Mallegni, F |author7=Chiarelli, B |author8=Dupanloup, I |author9=Bertranpetit, J |author10=Barbujani, G |author11=Bertorelle, G | title = Evidence for a genetic discontinuity between Neandertals and 24,000-year-old anatomically modern Europeans | volume = 100 | issue = 11 | pages = 6593–7 | issn = 0027-8424 | pmid = 12743370 | pmc = 164492 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | url = http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=12743370 | format = Free full text | bibcode=2003PNAS..100.6593C }}</ref> His racial presentation of the Cro-Magnon is in contrast to [[Jean M. Auel]]'s view in her ''[[Earth's Children]]'' series. Auel's initial book, published a few years later than ''Dance of the Tiger'', portrayed Neanderthals as light-skinned and Cro-Magnons as more racially varied, either light or dark-skinned. The author himself says "The book is not intended to be a 'theory about interaction between Neanderthals and Modern Humans', it is just a fictive description of one possible scenario among several that <u>might</u> have taken place".
Cro-Magnon children and adults are portrayed as having smooth brows and small faces; the characteristic features of childhood act as "innate releasing mechanisms" for feelings of affection.
:''To the Whites, the Blacks were godlike, tall and eloquent, with a speech as varied and flexible as that of the birds. And there was something else. No White could look at the clear brow of a Black without feeling a mysterious tenderness, such as a child might evoke in the heart of his parents.'' (Kurtén, p. 33, 5th printing, paperback)
Kurtén postulates that this attraction led to intermarriage between the two people, which produced sterile offspring. He emphasizes the possibility of Neanderthal extinction through inter-breeding rather than through violence. He also presents social differences between the two groups, presenting the Cro-Magnon people as more aggressive, practicing slavery and choosing violence to solve social problems. The Neanderthal society, based on a matriarchal system, is drawn as peace-loving with elaborate social rituals designed to resolve problems.
==Reception==
The novel is known for its plausibility and accuracy. Kurtén's supposition that Neanderthals and ancestors of modern ''Homo sapiens'' occupied same areas in the same time in Europe has been confirmed by fossil evidence.<ref>[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=the-mysterious-downfall Twilight of the Neanderthals] Article in ''[[Scientific American]]'' August 2009 by [[Kate Wong]]</ref>
:''Kurtén has managed to insinuate into his story — in a way so subtle and natural that we can scarcely recognize he is teaching as well as novelizing — every fact and theory that I know (and several, undoubtedly, that I don't) about Neanderthals, Cro-Magnons, human evolution during the Ice Age, glacial geology, and ecology and behavior of the great Ice Age mammals, including mammoths and saber-toothed tigers.'' ::::[[Stephen Jay Gould]], introduction to ''Dance of the Tiger'', 1980.
Kurtén wasn't the first novelist to examine the subject; for instance author [[William Golding]] also examined the issue of Neanderthal extinction in ''[[The Inheritors (William Golding)|The Inheritors]]''.
==Release details== * Originally published as ''Den Svarta Tigern'', ALBA Publishing, Stockholm, Sweden, 1978. * English translation copyright, 1980, Björn Kurtén. * English translation, Random House, New York, 1980. * Pantheon Books paperback editions, initially published September 1980, Fifth printing October 1983. {{ISBN|0-425-06477-8}}.
